raw_text.538: lavish and unique the bees is a study in world building laline paull has taken a dissertation's worth of dry facts about apian culture and transformed them into a dripping droning vibrating multi caste tale of a beehive i nearly set aside this anthropomorphic dystopian thriller early on because well it's an anthropomorphic dystopian thriller i did animal farm as a sophomore in high school i wasn't keen on revisiting those salad days but laline paull's gorgeous writing and my immediate affection for flora 717 the underdog sanitation bee hee pulled me in like oh damn a bee to honey paull's orchard hive is enchanting it is a castle complete from corridors and antechambers secret passageways and nurseries great halls where tales are told in a furious shuffle of delicate feet and trembling antennae and orgies of nectar unfold amidst throbbing abdomens and gaping spiracles the hive presided over by the beloved queen thrives according to a carefully tuned social hierarchy from the lowliest sanitation worker and hard working foragers to the crafty teasel nurses callous fertility police and prescient sage priestesses this is a matriarchal society--a ripe sensual emotive world where females are bossy bitchy weepy nurturing subservient and often in a state of warm sweet tumescence males are occasional visitors arriving as drones in a cloud of henry viii bawdy revelry flirting with bee wenches getting sloppy drunk and generally making a mess of things with spilled bodily fluids flora 717 a preternaturally gifted sanitation bee is our guide into the hive mind though ugly and besmirched by her low caste she is strong resourceful and clever her gifts are noticed by a sage priestess and flora advances through the ranks of the hive until she becomes a forager one of the true worker bees who leave the hive in search of nectar and pollen to feed her sisters flora 717's forays into the world beyond the hive are great fun she runs into bewitching spiders is lured into a sugar snare by wasps nearly eaten by crows and sucked in by a carnivorous plant her fur coat is pummeled by rain her wings nearly defeated by wind she discovers the delights of gardens in full bloom and laments the poor cultivated plants that will never know the flower bee communion of pollination and harvest although rich in description and scene setting the bees is thin of plot for all the activity around her flora 717 is a singular character had she interacted with bees of a similar strong nature and evolving consciousness and embarked upon adventures that raised the stakes there would have been more to this story but she seems to be the only bee that can move among the ranks and the only one capable of independent thought this as well as her mysterious ability to produce eggs the strange poison brought into the hive by hapless foragers and the odd mythology of the six panels are among the plot threads left dangling after a while the dancing and feeding and descriptions of how nectar and pollen and wax taste and smell and feel and elicit orgasmic reactions in the hive's residents become filler prose meant to round out where the story itself falls short in various reviews of the bees i have read that this book is about racial identity environmental degradation a riff off margaret atwood's classic deconstruction of fertility the handmaid's tale a reflection of hive mind politics and the dangers of a totalitarian state an allegorical tale of class and society oookaay nope really it's just about bees a fantastical rich imaginative look into the life cycle of the amazing little bee and its vast community i will never look at a bee again without wondering how far away she is from home and what messages she sends through her legs and spiracles and the humming of her wings

humanoid characteristics but emphasize the alienness of their society it didn't work because you really can't have it both ways so we have the bees wearing lace and drinking wine and singing a botched version of the lord's prayer just why in one chapter but in the next they're acting exactly like you'd expect insects to act it's very hard to reconcile this idea of bees who braid their hair and eat pastries with the idea that they simultaneously spend all day either a visiting flowers b feeding larva or c build honeycomb describing the bees as having "hands" and "faces" didn't seem to fit at all raw_text.557: really 3 5 stars this is one of the most original books i've ever read the story is told from the point of view of a bee flora 717 and touches on the dystopian elements that naturally arise in hive living it was a fascinating tale that will forever change the way i view bees and the other insects aka the myriad they come into contact with flora 717 is born a sanitation worker the lowliest position in her hive but because of special skills she possesses namely the ability to speak and produce flow she's promoted to work in other areas of the hive but when she breaks the first law of hive living only the queen shall reproduce flora's faith in her hive is shaken and she must decide whether her loyalty lies with her egg or her sisters i was initially going to give this book 4 stars but after my book club's discussion where a couple key plot points facts were debunked i docked it a bit more the main things i struggled with were 1 bees do live in a hierarchal society but it's not dependent on being born into a specific clan but rather on age and 2 view spoiler while female worker bees do lay eggs there is no way that flora could've produced a female egg given the genetics they would all have to be drones hide spoiler however there was a lot in this book that was accurate and i learned a ton the only other con was that i couldn't really relate to flora and her struggles she faced so many obstacles throughout the book but there was always this distance this alienness with her that kept me from being completely engaged this is probably because well she's an insect but i still would've appreciated a better understanding of her voice all that being said this book made for the best discussion my book club has ever had and it changed my perspective on one small piece of the world i highly recommend it especially if you're looking for something different to read or are particularly interested in honeybees
raw_text.558: flora 717 is a sanitatation bee who is born into the lowest caste in her hive the sanitation bees clean up after the other bees and remove dead bees from the hive but from the very beginning flora 717 is different she is curious and smart and doesn't just go along with what's expected of her which is very little she quickly is able to feed newborns in the nursery she works as a forager gathering pollen and nectar to make into honey she then helps fight off a wasp which grants her seldom given access to the queen soon flora 717 is doing things that are never done in the hive things that put her life in jeopardy the motto of the hive is accept obey and serve but flora 717 is starting to realize things must change in order for the hive to survive she uncovers secrets and risks her life to do what she knows is right even if no one else agrees in the end her courage to go against the hive mentality of accept obey and serve will change not only her life but the life and future of the hive this is one of the most unique and interesting books i've read in a really long time on one level it's a unique look at the culture of a beehive from an insider's perspective but on another level it's also a story about power hierarchies risk and the importance of believing in yourself and doing what is right no matter what a fascinating book that i just could not put down

raw_text.575: first a disclaimer the publisher sent me a copy of this book via a goodreads giveaway this book should ideally be rated a 3 5 it wasn't quite to the really like it stage mainly because the few downsides were really annoying the good this is an amazing anthropomorphism of bee culture while the publisher stressed the handmaid's tale and the hunger games as similar to this book i found myself thinking back to the mists of avalon the goddess like reverence of the mother religion alone made me think of the druids in addition the language at times was courtly this actually became a major downside when it came to the drones they were just over the top perhaps this was intentional on the part of the author but it felt forced and sucked some of the good out of the story the main character is slightly more complex than the rest of the characters in the story but even she appears slightly flat at times the caste society of the bee world is interesting to explore the hive mind religion scent language and dance stories of the bees are all explored in this story the research and use of real bee information is impressive one does experience a wide array of emotions while reading this tale though not as much as you want flora's the main character inability to connect with her own kind as a different bee keeps her separated from her reader as well ultimately the ending was easily guessed with one small twist that feels slightly even uncomfortably wrong as for the few humans in the story i am now a bit wary of eating honey an interesting side note though it appears that this book is also being marketed to teens it is a bit of a dirty tale in some parts not so much sexually explicit though the mating of the queen is in there but the interactions with the drones and especially the interactions between the bees and the flowers are highly sexual in tone all in all the bees is very readable there are a few downsides that make it less than it could have been but for a read on the beach or a warm summer day in the garden it may be just perfect

raw_text.580: 3 5 stars this was a difficult book to rate because i didn't know where to place it is it a book that i will ever read again or even want to it's unlikely did i enjoy it though yes quite a bit as is so often the case i was totally unaware that there was any hype surrounding the bees back in may 2014 i saw it in waterstones because the cover was eye catching and then a few weeks after that i managed to find a copy in the library so i snagged it it's been sitting near my bed for months now and here it is in january that i finally get to read it so where do i start i've read books where the main characters are animals before and because they are anthropomorphised it makes it easier to relate to them as protagonists here it's hard because though the bees had traits and characteristics that we can recognise as human they are still essentially insects so they can come across as rather alien almost flora 717 was a decent character and i did feel for her as she went through the various adventures in her life i loved the atmosphere of the hivemind the hierarchy and the way it was controlled and ruled with a monarch and religious leaders on one page there was a mention of 'knowledge is power' and 'winter is coming' shoddily paraphrased and my mind instantly went to game of thrones there was definitely that feel to the book of power plays and squabbles over reigns and class differences when it comes down to it though it takes you out of the story sometimes when you remember that you are reading about bees so to read about bee priestesses swinging censers and the workers eating in the canteen and there being a patisserie it plays with your head a little i liked that view spoiler the forbidden love the blurb spoke of was that of a motherly love rather than romantic love it added a different element to the story being told although not being knowledgeable about apian sexual reproduction i had no idea how flora was getting pregnant in a manner of speaking as soon as we found out that her third egg was a girl though i cottoned on that it would go on to be the new queen so the ending wasn't a surprise to me and flora's death made me sad such a short life and so full of hard times and hard work and ultimately her fate was to give birth to a queen and die hide spoiler overall some good things here there was some beautiful writing really lovely descriptions and insights into the way the bees saw and interpreted the world around them the research was obviously very good and it made me want to do some research of my own this was a unique book with unusual characters and though it wasn't quite there it was enough to keep me reading

raw_text.605: this book was absolutely beautiful surprisingly so i admit that i only picked it up because it was compared to the handmaid's tale and the hunger games i won't say i completely disagree with those comparisons but i feel it held much more in common with watership down in the same way that adams makes us a part of the rabbits' lives paull does that with bees i have no idea how accurate the portrayal of bees lives was but it certainly felt realistic and logical as i read paull's bees are deeply spiritual religious and devoted we hear the phrase hive mind bandied about to describe many things but reading this book actually allows you to experience a hive mind from the inside i hope bees really are like the bees in this story i don't like to summarize plots and possibly spoil new readers so i won't but i would like to say that the ending made me very very happy with the exception of a very brief foreword and an even briefer afterword this story is told from only the bees' perspective the opening and ending pages allowed me to put the story into the context of my human life everything that happened within the pages of the book could be happening all around me every day the fact that paull made me feel fear anxiety relief and panic about bees is a testament to the skill displayed in the writing bees seem as if they might be boring when not stinging something thus dying but these bees never left me bored paull never left me bored

raw_text.643: the bees by laline paull is enchanting and masterfully written once started i could not stop reading it the book is written like a reality drama that takes place in a beehive flora 717 is a bee born to the lowest caste of the hive but she is different from her own in that she is larger of a darker color and she can speak she also has very high intelligence and blasphemy she can lay eggs every bee knows that only the holy mother is allowed to lay eggs and that for any other bee to do so means certain death besides being entertaining this book gave me a good education about how bees maintain the hive i learned much about the queen mother the nursery the foragers making wax and honey and found the information enhanced the story and led me to become more engaged flora's deep love for her queen and her loyalty to the hive encourage her to experience many adventures on her quest to be of service i came to care about flora and found myself cheering her on when she would buzz to her own drummer there is a messianic theme to the book the queen is regarded as the messiah a loving and all caring savior she produces life and love and perpetuity of the hive laline paull you have written an exceptional book it is a book that i will not forget i am waiting to see what journey that your wonderfully creative mind will take us on next
raw_text.644: it's hard to imagine there would be a compelling novel entirely starring insects but here it is the bees is an incredibly vivid look into the trials and travails of a honeybee hive and one worker named flora who is blessed with some incredible gifts one aspect of this book did disappoint me though the realism was disrupted by the bees occasionally carrying objects such as little dustpans and brooms and silver platters this out of place disneyesque touch was unnecessary paull cleverly works in some real life problems facing bees such as the devastating effects of pesticides and disease and after reading the harrowing description of a hive being plundered by human hands don't be surprised if you think twice about eating honey

raw_text.652: laline paull's novel "the bees" is the story of an ordinary individual low level worker bee named flora 717 and her extraordinary journey it sounds like a dubious premise upon which to base a novel and i was sceptical at first the concept felt to me to be too similar to the 1998 movie 'antz' in which woody allen is the voice of an existentially troubled worker ant who questions life's meaning when you are an anonymous being amongst millions the movie was a fun way to express aspects of human angst in an indirect way via anthropomorphism but it didn't give you much appreciation for the way consciousness must work differently amongst insects compared to humans paull's novel does this by showing you the way flora 717's thoughts and feelings are inextricably tied to the collective hive in doing so she creates a compelling tale which gives a fascinating perspective on social interaction hierarchies in society and will likely spark a keen interest in melittology the study of honey bees that you never thought you'd have read my full review at lonesomereader review of the bees by laline paull

raw_text.663: maybe 3 5 bees i like them i love the bee civilization laline paull has created with a mashup of almost unbelievably real facts and her own inventions and i like the accidental rebel bee flora 717 who shows us around the hive it's true that under this bee hive frame the setup is a classic dystopia but paull resists the temptation to moralize flora's adversaries are not evil for me this saves the bees from being lumped in with the armies of forgettable dystopian novels that have come out in recent years but i can see how it might feel unsatisfying or meandering to others for it's lack of a message the closest thing to a lesson here is minor spoiler agricultural pesticides kill bees a note about differences between editions i started this as an audio book from my library and finished it in paperback form switching back and forth between versions in the middle the narrator for the audio book does a great job but at times there's excessive flowery pun description which would drive even me a lover of flowers u0026amp purplish prose nuts if i was reading rather than listening i noticed that my paperback edition had in fact undergone a substantial further edit in this regard in summary i enjoyed this book and recommend it some stretches are a bit slow and repetitive which is what kept me from giving 4 stars

raw_text.697: a birthday present from my mother in law i'd never heard of it though since receiving it i've seen it all over the place creating a lot of buzz i'm sorry couldn't help myself paull vividly brings to life the completely alien world of the bees allowing an appreciation of how life and communication through scent dance and religious divinity may work it's a complex task which she pulls of handily the story itself feels more prosaic almost formulaic with our strong minded heroine's path relatively easy to predict it also felt clumsy especially in the first half situations lurching around without pause though when your lifespan is so short maybe that's what life feels like free wheeling from one mishap to the next adventure with nary a pause the style grew on me though and i was enjoying it by the end it's an impressive work not necessarily amazing but it did open my eyes to different viewpoints on the way we interact with out planet it's also left me with a strong desire to learn more about bees i would recommend this as something different to the average thriller out there right now

raw_text.707: set in the orwellian world of a beehive's last days this book is strangely charming i had difficulty at first understanding because so much of the bee's communication was through scent but once i caught on it made sense the bees aren't sentimentalized or really even anthropomorphized it starts with the hive going about its business as usual except for one upwardly mobile bee named flora 717 it's not that she's ambitious she's driven by something she doesn't understand and has to hide to protect herself because anything out of the ordinary must be destroyed in this rigid society the tone of the book is serious as it's a life and death situation not just for flora 717 but for the whole hive i've always been fascinated by bees but you wouldn't have to share this interest to enjoy this book there's drama politics friendship and even love within the hive i think the author really did her research and painted a fairly realistic portrait of life in a beehive

raw_text.723: read the full review at jenna does books the bees by laline paull is undoubtedly the most unusual book i have read in at least a decade or more the story does for bees and religion "group think" and society roles what animal farm did for barnyard animals and government the bees has transformed this reader i have a deeper curiosity and respect for an animal that i once looked at with nothing more than revulsion and fear i'm not saying i'll be going out and making friends with my neighborhood bees anytime soon but at least now i can understand their position but i digress...while i disagree with the comparisons to the handmaid's tale and the hunger games that the bees has been receiving i can see the reasoning behind these comparisons fans of the hunger games will recognize the oppression of "the people" and admire flora 717's determination the overall "feel" of the novel of a young bee's "coming of age" and questioning the structure of her current society will also be a major draw for ya readers with that in mind this comparison may be a smart marketing decision overall as for the handmaid's tale i suppose you could find some logic in this when you consider the hierarchical position of the bees in the hive and flora 717's struggles in the later half of the book but when it comes to the overall tone plus the direction of the story and the manner in which it is told i cannot help but compare the bees to animal farm this book is dark y'all this book has a statement to make as i have already said the bees does for religion what animal farm did for government i see this book as high school or college reading material some day or at least i hope it will be this is a story whose topics will easily withstand the passage of time and are so important for future generations read the full review at jenna does books

raw_text.735: 3 5 stars really strange book and though i was interested enough to read to the end after the first third which was a bit of a slog i'm still a bit divided about it i thought the setup which is kind of the handmaid's tale meets watership down meets 1984 slash animal farm was interesting and i like what she took on with world building--in this case a beehive but the storyline got repetitive in places which ended up making the social commentary feel heavy handed and that kind of thing is always better in less is more mode as far as i'm concerned also it was somewhat hard to latch on to the main character especially once the drones--the males--came into the picture and were given all personality in the story which i realize was the point the hive is full of female bees that are basically interchangeable within their given roles and this is what happens when one bee breaks out of hers i get it but there was something slightly off putting about the males being the only really interesting personalities at least until the main character's hubris kicks in but in spite of those complaints it kept me reading the world building was a lot of fun and the fact that the world was a beehive was fascinating in itself i think in the end what flattened it for me was how little humor or any sense of irony there was even a serious book has room for a bit of edge and i wish there had been more still it was such a different book--which ultimately kept me reading straight through so kudos to paull for pulling it off

raw_text.740: this was a novel that won me over at first some of the anthropomorphic elements reminded me too much of an animation such as a bug's life with the bees using tools and doing things no actual bee could i had been pre warned about this by other members of the shadowing reading group however the power of the narrative about flora's own progression and the nature of the hive society with its rigid caste system had a great deal to convey about many themes so that mild irritation faded quickly and i could appreciate it as a fantasy that in its own way dealt with aspects of our own society as well as shining a light on the environmental issues that are threatening our bees i did find that reading the novel made me more interested in the natural history associated with bees and i was going on line to check various aspects there are themes that call to mind 'brave new world' and in a number of reviews 'the handmaid's tale' is also cited and yet i felt this was a unique and highly memorable novel could it win the baileys prize it would be a brave choice given the subject matter and there will be those that will not look beyond the surface to see themes relevant to our world i know that the story of flora 717 will remain with me

raw_text.787: three and a half stars from me i was first attracted to this book in foyles where the beautiful bright yellow cover immediately attracted my eye but it was not until i read the intriguing synopsis that i knew i had to read it told from the point of view of a bee flora 717 is an unlikely heroine in a world that demands uniformity and perfection with no deviation from the norm allowed it's been described as a cross between the handmaid's tale and the hunger games and i can easily understand the comparisons but i think it's also similar to books such as 1984 and brave new world as a fascinating look at how a society can be brain washed into believing certain ideals for the greater good as they imagine it flora 717 begins her life in the hive as a sanitation bee the lowest caste of all bees and nothing is expected of them except to make sure the hive was clean at all times however it's not long before the higher caste bees begin to realise that flora is no ordinary bee for a start she can speak a function not given to the lower castes as it is not usually required she can also produce flow the substance given to developing larvae and for a while flora is put to work in the hive nursery feeding and taking care of the infants she is then given the opportunity to become a forager i e searching outside the hive for as much pollen as she can carry back and becomes rather good at it even her bumblebee dances which explain to the other foragers where to get the best pollen and warn of any potential dangers are praised and looked forward to on a daily basis it is not long before flora is admitted into the inner sanctum of the hive where the queen resides attended to by high priestess bees once again her intelligence and talents surprise everyone and surpass everything ever seen before from regular bees it looks like life can only get better for flora with ears in such high places then something happens that has the potential to threaten everything she has ever known flora cannot help her response to such a situation and as a result must try desperately to hide her secret as much as she can this is dangerous territory especially when their holy mother the queen is having problems of her own in a sensitive area that involves the future of the hive furthermore the hive mind will always seek out any mutant bees or rogue thoughts in their midst that cannot be controlled by the sweet pheromones pumped out by the queen bee this was a really interesting and unique read a dystopian fantasy from the perspective of a creature we normally take for granted the humble bumblebee i loved flora as a main character she had just the right amount of tenderness and rebellion to make her exciting and so very readable the author has clearly carried out astute research into the life of bees yet i still had to laugh at the mental images i was getting of these little insects such as sweeping the floors and doing their little explanatory dances never fear adrenalin junkies there are also plenty of action sequences in this novel as we see the hive battle enemies such as mice spiders and their old adversary the evil wasp then there are the princely male bumblebees which provided an extra bit of humour as they were preened and doted on by the females before finding their own mate outside of the hive to be honest i don't really have much to criticise about this book it was slightly slow in the beginning but as i settled into the style of writing i began to love flora and all she stood for if you're an animal lover or intrigued by the world of bees specifically this is the perfect book for you i learned a lot but i was also highly entertained which of course is the main thing for my full review please see my blog at http www bibliobeth com

raw_text.799: there's lots of buzz about this book and most of it is well deserved it's the story of a hive and of a particular bee in that hive flora 717 is a sanitation bee in an orchard hive humans placed it there and she is a little different from her fellow sanitation bees sanitation bees do the dirty work in the hive they clean up bodies of dead bees and other messes that occur they are low in the bee hierarchy although most of the bees be they foraging bees nursery bees drones etc all repeat the mantra of the hive accept obey serve but our bee flora 717 has a different story she is different from the other bees she is a breakout bee who thinks for herself and has abilities the others don't have even though she si regarded as not only ugly by the others but as the lowliest kind of bee until the queen bee takes notice this book is truly a cross or homage to atwood's the handmaid's tale and orwell's 1984 animal farm the setting is dystopian a society struggling to survive but reluctant to adapt as the world around them is changing well written and with a fairly compelling story line there were a few sections where i became mired down and wished for sharper editing the bees activity even that of the heroine flora sometimes became repetitive i guess that reflects the life of the hive and the hive mind dull repetitive mechanized without feeling or more importantly without time or energy fro feelings flora a sanitation bee with her own mind and a voice cannot help but fight against the melissae and the fertility police i did love the references to the melissae which means the bees in greek the melissae in ancient greece were a group of priestesses that were honored as having regenerative and magical powers much like bees and the greeks did indeed keep bees and appreciated their magical powers to create honey and come back after the winter to make more this is a physically beautiful book i love the cover even the arc copy was gorgeous as is the hardcover i'm giving this novel 5 stars although i feel 4 5 would be more appropriate great novel although not perfect and i expect great things from this author in the future it would have been really cool if she raw_text.804: when i first heard of this book i thought the author would take in one of two ways 1 human character live in a fantasy world that very closely mimics how real bees live in a hive 2 an anthropomorphic take in which bees are given human emotions and thoughts but otherwise act according to actual bee behavior i would have been fine with either of these although i do think someone needs to write #1 but sadly the author choose to go all crazy and have actual bees behaving like humans from the drones turned into worshiped frat boys going around looking for blow jobs to the strange caste system she uses that could not be more unlike the real bee hive system this book is just weird why you would write a book about bees that has nothing of real bee life or behavior in it why bees it might as well be kangaroos it would make little difference if you're just going to arbitrarily choose an animal than ignore everything real about that animal for instance she uses an instance of a layer worker bee to fuel her story uh no layer worker bees only happen in hives where there is no queen and this layer worker can only produce drones male bees she can't lay female worker bee eggs certainly she won't lay defective females that have to be hunted down and killed and the whole caste system made me crazy every female worker bee works all the jobs in the hive by the end of her life she starts out as a cleaner and over the course of her six week life span she spends about a week in each job ending up as a flower visiting field bee it's sad that all the people who read this book will come away with such a misguided view of how bees really work together and function a hive is a marvelous wonderful thing and this book just trashes that by making it ugly and nasty unable to get all the way through this mess because it made me too angry and sad

raw_text.812: 1984 with bees this is a beautiful well integrated book where seemingly opposing concepts are fit together into a smooth whole paull masterfully melds anthropomorphism with animal science behavior something i have never seen a novel truly attempt much less succeed at multiple levels of communication vocal pheremones dance are used to the benefit of the overall immersive experience even when bee human do not mesh paull simply inserts the dichotomy without disrupting overall coherence her lack of apology makes for a better read as these insect human cannot fully overlap and pausing to point this out rather than flowing through it would only bring the reader out of the story and out of believability although there are elements of a dystopian novel the reason why this book gets compared to 1984 this is not necessarily one paull navigates hive love vs personal identity without truly vilifying either although as independent humans our literature does ultimately favor the individual this book is at once a fascinating bee science lesson and a thrilling tale of personal development the only fault in this book is its last minute climax and rushed denouement yes i had to google story structure to refresh my memory of those terms but these ultimately unnecessary tacked on elements can be forgiven by the beautiful building lead up

raw_text.855: okay so how do i explain this the novel the bees is about well bees no big surprise but hold on right there why is it classified as science fiction it's an animal story right not really actually not at all the bees is one of the best dystopian novels i have ever read yes - i said "dystopian" the story follows a particular bee flora 717 who is from the lowest class of bees in a highly regulated highly stratified social structure ruled over by a small class of elite bees however flora 717 learns early that she sees things and does things and thinks things that members of her class should not be capable of seeing doing or thinking those oddities bring her into conflict with her society and challenge it to the point of immense danger to her existence sound familiar it should the story of flora 717 blends elements of the giver 1984 a brave new world handmaid's tale the hunger games ... and just about any other great dystopian novel you can think of and to make the story more compelling every component of the telling no matter how bizarre or unbelievable is based on real science about the behaviors and capabilities of real bees i found myself researching bees thinking "that can't be true" only to learn that it is true and then to lift the story to an even more compelling level the tale veers from dystopian to apocalyptic as the hive - the world of the flora 717 - is threatened with destruction and as fate would have it noble and heroic flora 717 holds the key to the ultimate life or death of the entire hive the bees is one of the most imaginative and compelling novels i have read in a long time and i will never look at the humble bee the same again oh honey

raw_text.866: laline paull's 'the bees' was an enjoyable and easy read however due to a few issues i found with it i unfortunately cannot give it any higher than 3 stars first the positives the basic premise of the book one bee's plights within its hive was fascinating as someone who is somewhat fond of bees i gave one some sugar water once because it had crashed out in my back garden it showed me the complexities of a world that i had never fully imagined although i'm no bee expert it all sounded fairly legitimate and paull does list a host of experts in her thanks at the end of the book it offers a reflection on our own world whether than is human society culture or even our impact on the earth itself which proved insightful it is vaguely dystopic in the sense that a totalitarian hierarchical societal structure will inevitably be and presented religious experience in a thought provoking way indeed at one point i wondered if it was essentially going to be a retelling of the birth of christ despite the brilliant premise there were times where the writing didn't quite do it for me in sections the word 'love' was repeated frequently in a short space of time there are other examples but this is the one that immediately comes to mind and it did get to the stage where i wondered if paull could have found a thesaurus or rephrased a sentence additionally at times i felt that there was too little dialogue or meaningful dialogue rather perhaps in the highly impersonal world of the hive meaningful relationships were always going to be hard to come by especially for a low ranking bee such as flora and although i expected her to fall in love with another character this was more out of generic expectations rather than it feeling genuine within the course of the narrative my final major gripe with this novel is that although a lot was at stake it never truly felt like it a creative writing tutor of mine tells us to always 'up the stakes' if a character wants a glass of water make it read as if they really really need it and that terrible things might happen if they don't this is of course hyperbole but i think the point stands even as something as seemingly little as a glass of water can hold the highest importance to someone at one moment in time the opposite occurs in paull's novel whereas great things are at stake and i mean really really important things it never quite passed in to the writing i knew that these things were important but i never truly believed that they would be lost and it felt rather 'so what ' if they were i'm unsure if this is intentional or not flora becomes more and more bold as the novel progresses but my initial and somewhat later thoughts tell me it was not perhaps paull needs to visit my tutor all in all i did enjoy reading 'the bees' i know i've listed more negatives than positives but that is in part due to my nature and also because i feel i would be labouring the first positive point if i were to go on and on the premise is fantastic but at time it is let down or even obscured by paull's writing i would give it another read even if it's just to visit the hive once more the plot twists and turns but ends in a rather linear and obvious place so for once i wouldn't read this for 'the destination' nor 'the journey' but for something else the scenery

raw_text.881: when i first picked up this book i was intrigued by the idea of a book that had honeybees as the characters i wondered if it was possible to make this work what i discovered was not only does this work but the book was so captivating that i couldn't put it down we are drawn into the life of the hive as flora 717 emerges from her cell in the arrivals hall the newly hatched bee quickly discovers that a strong and organized hive is made of a class system with strong sets of rules and one does not easily change her destiny despite being born a sanitation worker the lowest of the low in hive standards flora is brave strong and unusual she faces danger adventure persecution and finally comes face to face with her destiny through bravery and kindness she raises esteem for herself and her kin this book is a must read for a fresh perspective and a new appreciation for the world around us tbettina p marathon county public libraryfind this book in our library catalog

raw_text.912: what i was really looking forward to in the bees was the totally different mind set that would have to go along with being a bee and i'm delighted to say that the book really did provide it from the very start when flora 717 a lowly sanitation bee is born it's a whole different alien experience as she learns things essentially from instinct her rigid body unlocked and she calmed as knoweldge filled her mind this was the arrivals hall and she was a worker her kin was flora and her number was 717 things like the queen's love which is experienced with a kind of euphoria by all the bees--and which is genuine that is the queen really does love each and every bee--or the way pheromones like fairy glamour make not so attractive drones seem alluring--add to the effect and i enjoyed all those aspects of the story completely another quick example i loved the calming transforming effect a drop of honey has on flora the effect was immediate and astonishing clarity washed flora's mind and her body filled with strength i did however have a couple of reservations reservation one is that the plot is rather haphazard flora's an unusual bee and her talents keep on being called for in different parts of the hive now she's in the nursery now she's back to sanitation now she's called to see the queen... now she's a forager dramatic things happen a wasp attacks forgagers return contaminated by pesticides but they're isolated events you don't get a sense of them building toward anything because flora keeps on moving from one job to another she doesn't really get to develop any friends there are some lovely moments of shared bliss and sisterly solidarity but for a story of creatures with access to a group mind flora's rather painfully isolated the person who comes closest to a friend is interestingly the drone linden who's almost as unusual in his way as flora is in hers reservation two is for the whiff of dystopia that drifts by from time to time the dystopian elements the priestess class is scheming and hiding things from the hive do add coherence and drive to the story but really you could have all the same things happen and not have the hints of class struggle and i'm speaking as someone who's all for class struggle in the human realm to bring in class struggle is to suggest that somehow the whole bee hierarchy might be open to change... when really it's not the end represents a big shakeup but there's still going to be a queen nursery workers foragers... maybe with different kin in the roles but still those roles i felt that look at this cool society didn't sit well with it's dystopian though as i say though in spite of those reservations i highly recommend the story it's really alien and really fun
raw_text.913: a richly imaginative story allegorical in the way it tackled universal themes of gender racial inequality class struggle the tussle between personal and group identity the tyranny of religious orthodoxy and the courage to reject your assigned role in order to create your own destiny in a highly regulated society debut author laline paull managed to address all these important human issues through her main character sanitation worker bee flora 717 in an orchard hive in a soon to be sold disused farm flora 717 is thrust into the hive's society an entirely female social order in service to the revered male drones who eat drink and basically lord it over the sister bees though the male power is only virtual and ultimately shortlived when their purpose to the hive is served the sister bees are defined by their respective roles like the foragers the teasel sisters who are primarily nurses the priestesses with the sage sisters being the highest ranking and then the queen the object of worship who rules with the mantra accept obey serve reverberating within the hive mind in an all senses broadcast called the holy chord chiming through the antennae of each of the bees in the colony this social order is threatened when flora 717 is found to be an aberration which is dangerous to say the least in an environment that believes deformity is evil deformity is not permitted in a strange twist sister sage rescues her for an experiment and flora 717's life changes forever paull creates a very vivid picture of the world of her bees but while the story engages it never quite rises to a level beyond its caricature like nature as it tries to encompass all the themes observed above the cleverness of the allegory is a bright spark that impresses but does not last and the calamities that arise one after another within the claustrophobic confines of the hive becomes tedious rather than gripping the use of a framing narrative in the prologue and epilogue is also much too brief and feels rather flimsy

raw_text.917: laline paull's debut novel the bees is one that's going to stick with me for a while paull's understanding of honeybees is impressive and her story compelling most of all it feels wildly innovative there simply aren't many books like this i struggle with where to categorize it is it fantasy not in the traditional sense it's certainly not nonfiction though there's enough solid scientific information about honeybees here to get a new beekeeper off to a good start it's a family drama a tragedy an environmental piece it defies easy categorization perhaps the best books do the genius of paull's novel lies in her ability to simultaneously tell the story of an individual flora 717 a sanitation worker and a society the orchard hive in which she lives and labors this is much more than a simple story of protagonist versus society because as a honeybee flora's consciousness and her entire being are intimately wedded to the health and fate of her colony in a way that human individuals' aren't from devotion to the holy mother the queen bee to her evocation of the hive mind an entity at once linked to and separate from the queen paull brilliantly conveys the nature of these most social of insects they are at once a metaphor for humanity and something separate from us creatures who both resemble us and differ from us enough to have something to teach us but paull's novel is far from didactic we receive the story from flora's perspective alone experiencing all her fierce joys and conflicts in the end her triumph is neither in complete separation from the hive nor in complete integration within it this is a story of evolution not of the one but of the many in a time when honeybee colonies are disappearing at alarming rates flora's tale is well worth reading it portrays the difficulties facing honeybees with sharp clarity and immediacy but it's also worth reading as a window onto the human experience both because we too are conflicted social creatures with a perverse streak of independence and because our fate is intimately tied to that of the bees as an amateur beekeeper of four years i applaud paull's in depth knowledge of her subject as a writer i appreciate her ability to convey the complexities of hive life in a way that's accessible for the non beekeeper as well as any beekeeper knows there is a profound beauty and tragedy to the life of a hive that rivals anything human culture can produce in the end the best i can do is to suggest that this is a book in the tradition of watership down a richly detailed portrait of a society at once so similar to and different from our own that it deserves our attention and rewards our careful reading with new insight into the world and our place in it

raw_text.925: what a prosaic title for such a wonderfully imaginative book flora 717 is born into a beehive in an orchard into the flora the lowest cast in the hive soon she learns obedience and service are the by words for this society next to her as she hatches a new young bee whose wing is deformed is summary dispatched by the fertility police but flora's horror at this is forgotten as she is bathed in the scent of love that periodically emanates through the hive from the queen the beautifully realised world of the hive is a cross between a medieval court and a nunnery everyone has their place and any deviation is not tolerated and above all the queen is hidden behind a wall of her priestesses called the sister sages flora's life would have been one of short tedious service if she hadn't been born with special talents she can talk and the rest of her class can't plus she's big and robust her qualities are noticed and she's given the chance to perform different roles as a nurse in the hatchery as a forager bee seeking out nectar and pollen and she even gets near the queen but flora harbours a terrible secret that if exposed would see her instantly executed paull has written something like a fantasy adventure but all set within the confines of the hive her ability to make the life of the bees come alive with its beauty and terror is quite remarkable the hive itself has hidden chambers and multilevels and the various ways of communicating through scent vibration pheromones the bee dance in the dance hall are wonderfully evoked flora 717 is a feisty brave character and her friend amongst the drones they lie around like dandies while the female bees feed and groom them and worship their maleness sir linden brings humour and poignancy towards the end as waves of misfortune hit the hive the tension is ramped up and flora has to fight for her own life and ultimately that of the hive there is nothing twee about this book it is a thrilling adventure full of the pleasures of a strange world richly realised

raw_text.929: this book is marvelous it's been a very long time since i could not put a book down and read until 3am with this one i was torn between racing to find out what happened to the main character a bee flora 717 and slowing down to savor paull's sensuous writing style from the time she hatches flora 717 is different from the other bees of her ostracized but necessary caste the sanitation bees flora is bigger and darker than her fellow sanitation bees and she can speak publicly realizing her value to the hive the priestess bees assign her to the nursery she gradually shows her skill in other areas and the priestesses assign her to other tasks following the idea of a caste system the bees can only do the work that is assigned to their own caste they cannot switch jobs even so no one forgets that flora 717 was meant to be a pariah and she sometimes uses her unclean and invisible status to her benefit religion and worship are literal opiates of the masses daily the queen secretes a hormone that soothes the lower bees she is their goddess and that secretion is her life gift to them without the secretion they become agitated with the secretion they are docile and work without complaint fertility is a major theme in the book and the bees' highest law is that only the queen can breed in a hive that is overwhelmingly female their fertility is constantly policed the fundamental feminine act of ovulating carries the punishment of death by ovulating a female worker blasphemously assumes queenship this is the source of the marketer's comparison of the bees with the handmaid's tale but i disagree with that comparison these books have contrasting views on fertility whereas the handmaid's fertility was viewed as lowborn and a necessary evil even to the handmaid the bees' queen's fertility is sacred it is the divine act of creation fertility literally glows golden in this book i was enraptured by paull's highly descriptive style the hive is governed by scents every bee has a scent that is endemic to her caste the higher bees can subdue the lower bees by pushing their scent into the air the bees also communicate often abrasively with one another through touch higher bees will thrust their antennae at the lower bees in order to control their thoughts the oppressive confines of the hive are used well by paull there is no escape for flora 717 because there are bees and potential spies everywhere eventually when flora 717 is permitted to leave the hive the hive is juxtaposed with the vast blue freedom of the dangerous world paull's writing is exemplary when she describes the flowers as a gardener currently in the haunch of winter i could smell the flowers that she described i remembered the feel of the petals against my fingertips i knew the scents of wet dirt i miss the cloying smell of nectar her descriptions are a love letter to flowers the end is satisfying and i am sad that i finished it and have left flora 717 i hope i can read more by laline paull

raw_text.932: this was really fantastic it was almost like a 1984 brave new world hybrid except with bees what is there not to love really also i'm in love with the cover the inside cover is black and it's just overall pretty and i enjoy it immensely it is set in the totalitarian society of a bee hive and begins with the 'birthing' of flora 717 she is born into the lowest kin in the society who work sanitation but she is different she can speak and has other abilities which mean she is spared from eugenic cleansing so she can be of use to the hive she lives through the trials and tribulations of life in the hive from wasp invasions to religious slaughters but when she breaks the golden rule 'only the queen may breed' the path becomes ever more rocky for her in this epic tale of aroma control and triumph i really enjoyed the way the author displayed flora's internal struggle between serving her hive and her queen and nurturing her potent maternal instincts i also found the parallelism and ultimately criticism to human life and its impact on the environment very interesting and thought provoking i never thought i would have such sympathy towards flying insects but laline paull brought that out in me and considering i was on holiday while reading this where the flying insects are a plenty i had these very perverse feelings of care and concern for them what was weirdest of all was that i seemed to relate to their plight for food because that is me all the time too i get you flying insects overall i would recommend this book i don't think i found it dull at any point and i gave it 4 stars

raw_text.938: this is a very impressive well written debut novel with a unique premise that transports the reader into a totally different realm i look forward to seeing what she does next i chafed a bit at the premise and the resulting structure initially our protagonist flora 717 is born as a sanitation worker but happens to be unusually large strong brave and prescient so she can and does perform pretty much every other possible role in the hive i thought the first third of the book lacked coherent purpose it felt a bit like paull was marching you through the beehive's various zones and castes to demonstrate her thorough research into bee culture this turns out to be crucial to the plot later but i found it a bit awkward at the time after about the page 100 mark the story settles its nervous ramblings and becomes more absorbing i liked the way that we like flora 717 are focused on the moment to moment needs of the hive leaving no room for articulated curiosity about why things are the way they are instead we are invited to think like a bee and experience the politics and perils of the world from that perspective i also found the brief human perspective prologue and epilogue to be incredibly touching they were fitting bookends to bring you from your human world down into the meticulous details of bee life and then back up and out again very well done

who had the capacity to even be different in the first place in some ways i feel like the bees failed at really making a good point and won't stand up next to animal farm or watership down with close inspection why is the society wrong shouldn't there be more examples of unfairness to other bees besides flora i can't tell if i'm just too picky and expect too much because dystopian novels are my raw_text.1001: won this on a goodreads giveaway as an avid fan of the animals of farthing wood i was really pleased when i won this and i was not disappointed here we follow flora 717 as she develops from a lowly sanitation worker bee to one of the most important bees in the hive this is a story that is powerful and moving on many levels and is very much character driven even with the characters being bees paull has re created the complexity of the world of bees beautifully in this book from the intrigicies of bee communication to the importance of the hive mentality this book brings all that to life and in such a way that the average person can understand it and more importantly appreciate it granted there may be some scientific inaccuracies but this is not what the book is about it is about showing the human society is not the most complex on this planet and that we are actually far out done by that delicate little bee that hovers around your garden flowers each day

raw_text.1006: thrilling and movingsince my high school days i've always been fascinated with the concept of dystopia blade runner stirred something in me 1984 changed the way i see the world and i can easily list the machine stops as one of my favourite reads of all time this is the main reason why i picked this book from a basket full of bargains in a tiny bookshop i must admit i only glanced at the back cover so later i was slightly surprised to find out it is actually about the insects and not an allegory of humankind in a distorted future but don't let this put you off the story is thrilling with a good share of cruelty and breathtaking moments although i wouldn't describe it as dystopian work per se its general atmosphere and dark vibes will give you that feeling the protagonist flora is just adorable and it is almost impossible not to feel for her while reading of her misfortunes you will probably find yourself teaming up with her and hating the hierarchic structure of the hive and the random like choices of mother nature the author's style is fairly sophisticated english is not my mother tongue so i actually had to look up a few words on the dictionary and it sometimes lingers too much in descriptions but the overall rhythm is fluent in dystopian literature the hierarchy and rigidity of society in a bee hive has been used as an allegory often enough but i found this book quite different and original in its own way

raw_text.1014: a complete immersion into a world of honey and nectar devotion and devastation the world of the hive is set up as a dystopian society where all accept obey and serve without question but flora 717 is no ordinary sanitation worker bee her strength curiosity and intelligence lead her all the way to the queen's chamber and out into the fields of pollen and nectar the religious overtones could be overwhelming but they are offset by the humor of the highly irreverent and slightly profane drones worship his maleness the last time i felt as caught up in an animal society book was watership down that's not to say these books are more than superficially similar for one thing watership down is told exclusively male points of view and the bees is exclusively female for another the bees feels much more insular which is fitting since their world is confined for the most part to a very small area watership down has a huge scale and scope but both do challenge the idea of what it means to be a rank and file member of society and both have those rank and file characters rising above their stations to possible greatness

raw_text.1018: imagine a world where more than 99% of the population are sisters and everything is controlled by their mother the queen in this world each individual is checked for perfection the moment it is born if a newborn meets society's standards it is allowed to live and serve if not it is viciously slashed to pieces hauled away and unceremoniously dumped imperfection is not tolerated a baby's social status is determined by society prior to its birth rank is determined by the kind and amount of food it receives each member of this world has an unshakable love worship relationship with the queen how is this possible mind control the queen keeps her clan under control doing her will and worshiping her via mind controlling drugs and a cadre of minions release and her status is enforced by the fearsome fertility police they make sure she is only one who has children lots and lots of children she also makes sure that the population is kept in a perpetual state of fear of the outside world enough so that only a select few even want to venture out and run the risk of falling victim to the myriad the collective danger and evil that lurks beyond the community's walls enter flora 717 a baby born into the lowest social order the untouchable cleaners flora 717 is not exactly perfect she's too big and is darker than she should be but the hive is short handed so an exception is made and she is allowed to live i was thoroughly engaged as i read this dystopian tale set in a beehive i was engaged in two different ways first this is a creative tale told from the frame of reference of a lowly bee who is different but who was allowed to live all the same secondly i was intrigued by the way the author used what we actually know about the biology bees and their interactions with each other and other things to enrich the tale not your usual dystopian tale but ended up being quite a page turner 5 stars

raw_text.1020: i heard about this book on a podcast that discussed great summer reads this book was on the list the story follows the lives of bees within a hive for a full season told from the perspective of a sanitation bee named flora the hive has a strict caste system which this particular bee manages to circumvent allowing her to fulfill most of the roles in the hive as she moves from role to role we learn how the hive operates communicates and thrives there are dangers from disease the smoke of the beekeeper internal wars from spiders and most especially from wasps the bees each belong to a kin their caste and they are each named for a flower with flora being the generic and most untouchable caste this fantasy is a story of love loyalty perseverance and faith the recitation of the prayers and the religious rites are fascinating it is well written but the plot is not as captivating as the language i enjoyed it enough to recommend as a quick entertaining read but it isn't a book that has a higher purpose beyond a light story unlike something like flight behavior by barbara kingsolver it did provoke an interest in how a hive really works however if this is based on fact as much as i think it is then the life inside a hive is incredibly complex and a wonder to behold given the risks to bee populations today the author may provoke people to care more about the risks that bees face in the environment today as there are fewer and fewer places to forage oh and it will give you pause about stealing their honey for our own pleasure

raw_text.1030: the cell squeezed her and the air was hot and fetid all the joints of her body burned from her frantic twisting against the walls her head was pressed into her chest and her legs shot with cramps but her struggles had worked - one wall felt weaker she kicked out with all her strength and felt something crack and break she forced and tore and bit until there was a jagged hole into fresher air beyond this was the arrivals hall and she was a worker her kin was flora and her number was 717 and thus was the worker bee flora 717 hatched into her hive large and ugly doomed to be immediately destroyed by the caliper wielding police deformity is evil deformity is not permitted flora was saved at the last minute by sister sage a beautiful and privileged bee of the priestess class who seems to have special plans for the abnormal bee the bees by laline paull is a strange mix of fantasy and nature story that details a year in the life of a honeybee hive as experienced by its inhabitants there is much curious biology do bees really secrete wax from between their bands of fur can virgin workers produce fertilised eggs and yes apparently some species do would one worker bee really be rotated through every task from nurse to forager but the energy and lyricism of the storyline quickly made me want to stop questioning the facts and just enjoy the ride in paull's imagination a hive is like a religious cult with the queen as the central focus the rest of the cult's members are placed in strictly enforced castes - from the priestesses who enjoy the most influence down to the untouchable sanitation class to which flora should belong - and order is maintained through daily access to the queen's love a chemical wash that soothes and brainwashes the hive secret police deal quick and deadly punishments to nonconformists and every worker is born knowing the hive's orwellian slogans accept obey serve from death comes life eternal only the queen may breed for comedic relief the rare males are portrayed as lazy and foppish - prone to praising the might of their own dronewood - but their ultimate fate involves one of the book's most violent scenes perhaps trying to explain the recent surge in colony collapse disorder paull's honeybees are under stress from climate change and a rainy season with not enough foraging days pesticides the lethal call of cell phone towers and their historic foes the myriad all natural predators from wasps to crows in a non obvious observation it might be the hive's policy of killing all abnormally shaped bees that has doomed them - without variation they can't possibly adapt to changing external conditions and if this is the ultimate point of the bees more should have been made of sister sage's mysterious treatment of flora and the latter's curious paternity i really did enjoy this story while i was reading it but now that it's done it feels like there was something missing something deeper still no regrets the bees was a worthwhile read

raw_text.1076: what did i just read this is the oddest book first please skip the comparisons to other books unless i missed it there's not really any relatable commentary on human behavior in this book which means it's not animal farm or watership down additionally the bees are acting as bees have evolved to act and will continue to act because it's beneficial to their genes so it's not really a dystopia either i e not the handmaid's tale ahem not even close or the hunger games for the most part the bees are bees acting like bees and doing bee things except for when they do slightly human things like needlepoint baking pollen bread and using dust pans those exceptions gave me some serious cognitive dissonance as to whether they were supposed to be perceived as humans or bees but having finished the book let me assure you that one would do well to picture them as bees and additionally to pull out the wikipedia honey bee entry for info visuals that said flora 717's journey is occasionally well boring so much happens in so little time that as a reader i got fatigued with the descriptions in spite of how it is implied in the book that her role behavior is special flora follows a very typical path for a worker bee quote above wiki article young worker bees clean the hive and feed the larvae when their royal jelly producing glands begin to atrophy they begin building comb cells they progress to other within colony tasks as they become older such as receiving nectar and pollen from foragers and guarding the hive later still a worker takes her first orientation flights and finally leaves the hive and typically spends the remainder of her life as a forager ms paull describes all these changes in near excruciating detail it does pick up eventually as in far less dragging but i don't think there's really an ultimate moral or message here there are themes of maternal love and conflicts in loyalty but no overreaching message in which case i think i would have rather read a nonfiction book about bees so that i didn't have to spend half my time teasing out what the author had made up oh there is a book that it's a little like charlotte's web in the way significant

raw_text.1106: the bees contains a number of things which would normally annoy me in a story the miraculous central character chosen one who is able to do almost anything a rebels against a rigid society plotline where the character takes a long time to rebel and a few others for the most part these work in this book the bees is the story of a lowly sanitation bee who is different from all of the other bees of her station in the hierarchal society of the hive she is almost a non entity then she is noticed by one of the priestess class and is taken to perform other tests as trials she soon learns that she is able to communicate care for the young and forage for food we learn as flora 717 does the various tasks and rules which the hive society perform and are governed by we are with her when she starts rebelling against some of these rules in secret i won't mention which ones specifically for spoiler restriction reasons the bees is a creative work truly delving in to the inner workings of anthophilial life at times the book drags a little but there is enough tension and mystery to keep the reader moving along although the end is going to be guessed by many readers they will still want to see how the specifics play out
raw_text.1107: every time i talked about this book a dystopia set in a beehive with literal bees people's faces would light up it's a great concept and one that i ultimately felt like the book didn't quite live up to hence the four stars i don't really write goodreads reviews but there are two things i want to mention i felt like the first fifty or so percent of the book was flora our heroine flitting from job to job learning about the hive and taking the reader along with her this is actually pretty accurate to real worker bees who change jobs as they age but it's not accurate to paull's fictional beehive regardless of whether it's accurate to which world though it felt disjointed and i wish the plot had been built a little differently so that we had earlier signs for instance that things were getting worse and worse in the hive that said once the plot really gets moving i found the book hard to put down and extremely satisfying emotionally resonant exciting scary and sometimes downright horrifying so i highly recommend the bees if you make it to the last third of the book and still want to put it down then by all means do but i bet you won't want to edit oh and it's only $1 99 on amazon so no excuses if you think it sounds interesting

raw_text.1113: i will never look at bees the same way again after reading "the bees" reading the novel inspired me to read about the life of bees i learned that many of the most extreme actions in the novel such as the expulsion of the drones and the fertility police and concepts such as the hive mind are true to known bee behavior this is a credible version of the complex world of bees and their conflict resolution told with poetic license religious references and some inconsistent anthropomorphization flora 717 is born a bee from the lowest caste of an orchard hive a sanitation worker like all her hive sisters she is bound to accept the motto of accept obey and serve she is a quick learner and her formidable size and strength enable her to take on tasks not usually associated with her kin these tasks include feeding the newborns in the nursery and foraging outside the hive for pollen and nectar her different roles bring her access to knowledge about the hive and she must decide whether to blindly be obedient to the rules or act in the best interest of the community one of the strengths of the novel is the characterization of flora as a brave resourceful heroine who feels emotions and takes chances the other characters are not as well developed but the male drones provide comic relief another strength is the setting of the hive a mixture of palace and convent and the countryside filled with flowers yearning to be pollinated and dangers in the forms of wasps spiders and crows the bee hive seems to be an analogy to a class bound society and the novel is a social commentary on the corruption of power it asks the question can one original and independent thinker change the course of a whole society flora 717 is the symbol of the power of knowledge to change

raw_text.1116: i picked this book up because i enjoy dystopian novels and watership down is one of my favourite childhood stories the bees is an interesting tale of what life might look like to a hive member in this case flora 717 a lowly sanitation worker that rises through the ranks we get to see many aspects of hive life through flora's eyes feet which interpret vibrations in the floor and antennae which she uses to sense scents moods and general 'bee talk' however in my opinion the comparison isn't fair although both books contain animal characters watership down contains characters i loved and cared for with strong personalities and traits the bees was an interesting blend of nature and fantasty combined with the metaphor of humanity an 'ancient society that was like a hall of mirrors to our own' as the authors comments but the characters didn't reach into me as much i did enjoy the descriptions of the hive with it's corridors halls antechambers secret passageways and nurseries but would have preferred that human artifacts such as brooms dustpans and the 'patisserie' hadn't been part of the story as they took me away from the natural behaviour of the bees all in all an enjoyable story and one i would recommend but maybe without all the hype and comparisons

raw_text.1140: i picked this up on audiobook as an editor's pick in an audible sale and didn't pay as much attention to the description as i probably should have i read another reviewer's summary this creative regency thought and speech tinged sci fi fantasy dystopian novel begins as flora 717 emerges from her birth chamber born of the flora caste the sanitation caste flora 717 is larger than those typical in her caste and has the capacity for speech not typical of her caste her kin these "deformities" require the police to administer the "kindness" removal by death to flora 717 it is flora 717's good fortune that she is save by the curiosity driven help and encouragement of sister sage of the priestess caste and so begins a life in which flora 717 will demonstrate her courage and resolve to save her hive time and again somehow i got the impression from this description that this book was a sf fantasy type story just drawing on the metaphor of bees nope this is actually a story about bees in a bee hive the author gets quite creative in anthropomorphizing the bees and the everyday life of the hive as the story follows a sanitation bee through a series of bee adventures it was an interesting picture of a beehive hierarchy which i'd consider more appropriate for young adult level readers however i was never really sucked into the story because the main bee character flora 717 never seems to really develop a personality or have any agency in the story almost all her actions seem guided simply by instinct or circumstance and you never feel she is an independent character or that she actually makes any meaningful decisions everything is presented as if she does it because it seems to be the right thing at the time so she drifts through a series of incidents and adventures but i never felt i could really cheer for her it was just like watching a series of predetermined events fall into place so interesting and unique idea for a story but ultimately felt a bit flat to me
