raw_text.1150: the bees is well about bees following flora 717 a sanitation worker and member of her hive's lowest caste the story follows flora's life from her emergence as an adult as she faces both the structured system of her hive and eventually the threats of the outside world flora is a most unusual bee questioning her position and world in a society that values order and structure eventually learning to embrace her curiosity to improve herself and her hive flora's orchard hive is a well developed society in itself combining bee biology and dystopian fantasy the life of each worker bee is predetermined by her birth and enforced by a kind of bee religion there is worship of the queen as "holy mother " and adoration of drones for their role in fertility paull incorporates some real biology here for example scent and forager dances are major means of communication while some anthropomorphism is to be expected there are some strange aspects of the story that don't quite work pollen and honey are served as pastries on platters and flora's sanitation worker kin use small bee dustpans to clean perhaps these are so jarring because the rest of the bee society seems so "real " but they were enough to take me out of the story at least briefly this is definitely a different sort of novel and mostly in a very good way the bees is an enjoyable story that celebrates both individuality as well as being part of a greater whole a review copy was provided through the goodreads com first reads program
raw_text.1151: anthropomorphism in literature is not unique there's 'the wind in the willows' and 'watership down' but they were primarily directed towards a children's readership - not to say they weren't popular with older readers this is the first one from my experience where the adults are the target audience and i still can't decide if it works or not what we have is an attack on the established social order the rulers have always come from a certain section of society from a certain class and here it's a sort of theocracy which rules by force of will together with a police force not too dissimilar to the nazi ss and the general acquiescence of the majority of the population the start of the challenge to this tradition is the birth of flora 717 who immediately after birth is declared an 'excessive variation abnormal' although it is suggested that she be destroyed as a matter of course the theocrats allow her to live and begin her journey of discovery in the world around her as well of her own abilities that's their first mistake and from then on it's only a matter of time before her existence in the hive will change things forever - or at least a change of personnel at the top the same relationships remain at the end as at the beginning flora is a worker her destiny is to keep the hive clean say nothing and do as she is told the mantra being 'accept obey serve' but flora only pays lip service to these commands and slowly she gets to know how the hive works how she can best use the situation to her advantage and although she isn't conscious of it herself she'll be the conduit for the dramatic and traumatic change within the hive one thing that i found slightly bizarre and really something i was unable to get used to was the idea that the bees weren't actually flying themselves but seemed to be sitting on some powerful engine the impression that paull creates is that they press a switch and a away they fly i found that most strange there's always parallels to be drawn from the animal or in this case insect world with what happens in out human society however the message that paull leaves us with is one more about the american dream if it still exists - if it ever was anything in reality than any real and fundamental change in the relationships within society she can't very well play a feminist card as hive is a matriarchy and the only males are not invited to spend the winter with their sisters and due to their ineffectiveness during the spring and summer their reward is somewhat terminal they had been parasitic so the lesson here is that they deserved the consequences at the end there is a change in leadership there is a change in where those leaders come from i suppose in a way there's an inversion of what went before the 'world turned upside down' but for the vast majority of the population of the new community now away from the polluted town and the industrial wasteland with which the original hive was surrounded there are still those who have to do the cleaning still those who risk their lives to feed the rest the lion's share in both quantity and quality going to those who do the least and still a highly structured and maintained hierarchy as they say 'the queen is dead long live the queen' not 'the queen is dead long live the workers'

raw_text.1156: flora 717 is a bee of the lowest caste a sanitation worker in her hive but the queen recognizes that flora is not like other bees she is special unlike other bees in her caste flora has the skills to perform nearly every job in her hive and is soon given more responsibilities courageous and strong flora's instincts will lead her to make daring choices that challenge the hive's hierarchy and change the hearts and minds of those who doubt her while a little slow at the beginning having taken me a good seven chapters to get into the setting and narrative of the story the layers quickly progressed into many well written action scenes that had no trouble keeping my attention i did experience some repetitive spots throughout and while i found them annoying enough to just about give up three quarters of the way through a friend advised me to stick it out i'm glad that i did because once i encountered the twist i had no trouble thereafter staying focused the story was action packed all the way until the very last chapter i have since read reviews comparing this to animal farm and the handmaid's tale because i have not read atwood's famous work of literature that is a comparison i cannot make but i did find similarities with orwell's book paull's novel certainly dissects social class within what originally comes off as a matriarchal society but is quickly followed by events and actions of the male inhabitants in the hive that would suggest differently battles for power and one society member's internal struggle with conformity and following her heart although very well written for a debut novel i did find the structure a bit chaotic at times and i thought the secondary characters lacked some much needed characterizations i don't recommend listening to the audible audiobook it really was not good the narrator constantly emphasized words incorrectly and she made nearly half the book's sentences sound as if they were questions at twice the normal speed i still found it nearly unbearable overall i recommend this to anyone who enjoys anthropomorphic tales that are a metaphor for progression and change in our current or dystopian raw_text.1172: i won this book in a goodreads 'first reads' giveaway i would probably give it a 4 5 rather than 4 stars i was instantly drawn to this book when i saw the cover and read the synopsis i was not expecting it to be as good as it was however 'the bees' follows the life of flora 717 a deviant bee who was born too large and too clever and should have been killed instead she learns to forage is drawn into the queen's inner sanctum and goes through changes that are forbidden in her hive but when she commits through no fault of her own the ultimate blasphemy against the hive code flora is prepared to do anything to protect the new love that she has found i did at first feel like i was a little thrown into the story the way that bees lived their mindsets their rules felt realistic but very strange and took a bit of getting used to but my goodness this story is so special that i've pretty much overlooked that completely paull has obviously done an absolute tonne of research on the behavioral patterns and the hierarchy of a bee hive and has worked hard to come up with potential reasons for this behaviour from the bee's perspective i liked flora as a character she was very well written strong and even relateable i also had a bit of a soft spot for sir linden i found him to be so funny fantastic world building an intriguing plot line and believable characters both heroes and villains alike made this story well worth the long awaited read for a full review see here http chasedbymyimagination blogspot

raw_text.1189: a brief summary of the bees flora 717 born to the lowest caste of the hive is an anomaly with a large build and considered ugly she is the only sanitation worker who isn't mute like all her hive sisters she is bound to accept the motto of accept obey and serve she is a quick learner and her formidable size and strength enable her to take on tasks not usually associated with her kin these tasks include feeding the newborns in the nursery and foraging outside the hive for pollen and nectar her different roles bring her access to knowledge about the hive and she must decide whether to blindly be obedient to the rules or act in the best interest of the community i learned that many of the most extreme actions in the novel such as the expulsion of the drones and the fertility police and concepts such as the hive mind are true to known bee behavior this is a credible version of the complex world of bees and their conflict resolution told with poetic license religious references and some inconsistent anthropomorphization one of the strengths of the novel is the characterization of flora as a brave resourceful heroine who feels emotions and takes chances the other characters are not as well developed but the male drones provide comic relief another strength is the setting of the hive a mixture of palace and convent and the countryside filled with flowers yearning to be pollinated and dangers in the forms of wasps spiders and crows i was fascinated by the various roles every bee played in keeping the hive running smoothly from the lowly sanitation workers to the nursery feeders to the ladies in waiting everyone has their role to play in order to keep the hive running including the dreaded police bees flora 717 steps outside her role but only because the hive is in trouble and needs her multiple talents the beehive seems to be an analogy to a class bound perhaps communist society and the novel is a social commentary on the corruption of power it asks the question can one original and independent thinker change the course of a whole society flora 717 is the symbol of the power of knowledge to change the book has been compared to the handmaid's tale but i honestly didn't see any similarities it has been awhile since i read tht but i know it left quite an impression and made me think while i enjoyed the bees it didn't leave the same impression

raw_text.1203: a winning combination of animal farm with the handmaid's tale this is a tale told from the point of view of a bee bee society as imagined by laline paull looks somewhat like india's caste system and our heroine flora 717 is born into the untouchables of the bee world the sanitation workers she's big ugly dark hairy and ignored but like all good heroines in all stories set in totalitarian hierarchical semi magical stories flora 717 is born a little bit different she's no ordinary sanitation bee she's special her specialness threatens the rigid control of the priestess caste the sage bees the sage sisters appear to be protecting their queen and the hive but have they become drunk on their own power so drunk they can't see there's a much bigger threat to the hive than a worker bee with unusual gifts and ambitions all the bee castes are named after a plant and the individual bees are numbers attached to their cast this is just one way that paull constructs a fictional bee society in a way that seems both true to bees and comprehensible to humans yes of course the whole novel relies on anthropomorphization but paull is pretty disciplined about keeping these bee characters as apiary as possible i can't imagine the amount of research she must have done i don't know that much about bees so i suppose she could have made absolutely everything up but i was fairly convinced she got bee biology and politics correct although the plot is fast paced and the characters engaging maybe the most outstanding thing about this book was the sensory imagery i've never read a book as focused on scent the bees are as reliant on scent as we are on sound so most descriptive passages are honey drenched and almost woozily fragrant the bees make their way through the hive by smelling their destination and reading the floor vibrations with their feet in the air the forager bees follow the almost literal call of particular flowers who yearn toward the bees in an almost sexual way other senses are called into play as well she spiraled and plunged the better to show her long shapely legs folded under her elegant body her tiny waist her full regal abdomen that tapered to a pouting golden bud flora began her descent toward a million tiny golden mouths each showed a faint ultraviolet line pointing to its well of sweetness and those florets stirred by her wingbeats murmured in pleasurable anticipation the scent of the priestesses faded as flora went deeper into the warm aromatic crosscrossing of her sisters their body heat blending their kin scents together into fragrance and gossip that's an assortment from randomly opened pages one of flora's talents is that she can make royal jelly for the larval bees an act that paull compares very believably to breast feeding as it opened its tiny mouth to cry its warm scent rose more strongly threaded with the delicate fragrance of the queen's love immediately two pulses began flickering in flora's cheeks and her mouth began to fill with sweet liquid sister teasel guided flora into the right position as the luminous drops spilled from her mouth they fell onto the larva baby and it stopped crying wriggling around to lap them up the drops thickened into a thin stream which pooled around the baby's body until it could drink no more writing any one of these passages would have exhausted me i can't imagine spending that much time trying to translate bee world into human language i don't know how paull did it and that she did is admirable enough but she actually manages to make a good story out of it as well it's not the newest story in the world as i mentioned above it's broadly allegorical enough to apply it to almost any grievance you might have you could call it occupy hive street with the workers as the uprising proletariat or it could be seen as analogous to protestants rising up against the totalitarian corrupt authority of the catholic church in the 16th century libertarians might celebrate it as individuals asserting their independence from a coercive government revolution stories are always interesting to me so i didn't mind that the general plot outline is old as time or at least old as the idea of revolution yet another vital angle to this story is the very real and very worrisome specter of hive collapse bees are in serious trouble these days and humans are just coming to appreciate how dependent we are on them and other pollinators while we don't know exactly what's causing the bee die off overuse and misuse of pesticides is almost certainly one factor and paull brings that into play flora 717 and her sisters face a number of challenges and human malfeasance is perhaps the biggest existential threat there are littler threats too which serve to move the plot along and keep the reader hooked evil conniving wasps clever prescient spiders horny lazy voracious drones a hungry mouse the beekeeper himself this aspect of the book was like charlotte's web which i mean in the best possible way i loved viewing the world through a bee's eyes seeing what challenges she faces and what pleasures she seeks i hope that someday soon this book is routinely assigned to high school students it's as clever and potentially as important as animal farm or fahrenheit 451
raw_text.1204: what is it like to be a bee paull's book comes about as close as you can get to an answer it is the story of flora a bee who is born into the lowest caste but has abilities beyond her kin at a time when the hive is in crisis her skills are needed but by stepping out of the hive hierarchy she is able to observe and question what she sees flora's life is elemental she faces death from predators and fights fiercely she struggles to survive the elements she experiences the joy of foraging and flight she is devoted to the hive without always knowing where her loyalty should be placed the thing that makes the book convincing for me is that the bees do not have complex inner lives they do not as human characters would have thoughts shaped by their past and imagined futures flora's and the other characters' lives are the product of their senses - pheromones electrical impulses the food they're given the desire to dance the need to shelter while i chose to read it as a book about bees rather than an allegory of the human condition it does raise the question how far is our consciousness the same

raw_text.1206: it took me a while to succumb to the charms of this novel i am a sucker for sentient animal stories but the level of anthropomorphism paull chose for the bees took getting used to maybe because it didn't always feel consistent on the one side of animal centric stories you have animal protagonists who behave more or less like the animals they are like buck in call of the wild a dog that more or less behaves like a dog on the other side you have the wind in the willows with mole and rat messing about it boats the bees falls into a messy between space where sometimes the bees act like bees and at other times they act like the borgias it probably bothered me more than it should have i started to think hmm why can the bees talk to other insects and to arachnids but not to the mammals they come across why should spiders have the gift of foresight isn't that cheating a little a cheap way to give the novel scope it wouldn't have if the spiders weren't so magical by midpoint though my resistance was completely gone and i was thoroughly enjoying the story i thought the end was so well done both endings actually the end to the main story about the bees which ended very satisfyingly and the coda end which is filled with delightful irony when the humans enter and demonstrate their unwavering mistaken belief that the world and all its wonders revolves around them

raw_text.1217: "accept obey serve"i liked this book sure it's being compared to "watership down" and "the handmaid's tale" - both exceptional works of fiction but this novel "the bees " was so unusual because it gave me a new appreciation for them ah those wondrous insects that are so vital to our environment i've had my share of bad experiences with bees my 18 pound bichon frise stepped on one and i had to rush him to the emergency vet to reverse the effects of the venom so any book that can change my opinion of an insect gets kudos from me after reading this novel i have a new found respect for bees it is so unfortunate that they have been dying off in high numbers from pesticides as reported in the news lately i think the author laline paull does a remarkable job of underscoring their importance in our world what is the story about it is about our brave little heroine flora 717 she is dark hairy huge and ugly we are present during her birth as she drags herself out of her cell of wax to when she eventually dies an old tired and aged bee but she lived a meaningful life isn't that what everyone strives for to some degree judged by her physical appearance she is classified as belonging to the disposable ranks of sanitation workers the lowest caste of bees in the hive floras although she may physically resemble her kin flora 717 is anything but average incredibly she can speak ask questions and comprehend knowledge this is no ordinary bee she reveals a mind of her own when not controlled by the hive mentality she can also produce flow or royal jelly an ability that only nursing bees are known to do to feed the newborn larvae and she develops a knack for foraging a skill that feeds the hive and is of vital importance to their survival flora 717 transgresses all boundaries inside her hive blessed with a courageous spirit and a restless mind she is a target of envy jealousy and pride noticed by the hierarchy for her strange abilities flora attempts to hide a secret that could mean her death or what they refer to as "the kindness " if revealed readers are treated to a brilliantly detailed and visceral description of life inside the hive there are moments of levity with the horny drones who are referred to submissively by the fawning females as "your malenesses " these ego inflated male bees have their "handmaid's tale" moment in a visceral and bloody scene wow i never saw that coming i recommend this book it's an interesting examination in the life of an extraordinary bee

raw_text.1227: most people myself included pick up this book because they hear its like a cross between watership down and handmaid's tale but with bees that's not a bad description but it sets up expectation that seem to leave a lot of people dissatisfied with the bees this seems a bit unfair to me first off despite all the lady bees gushing phrases like praise to his maleness at the awful male drones the males are bit players in this book it's a story about many castes of female bees from worker up to queen where males only play a tiny role which diminishes as the book progresses so people who want an allegoric version of handmaid's tale are going to be disappointed indeed despite caste themes that echo human conflicts over race and class this book shouldn't be read primarily as social and political commentary yes it contains the idea that group difference is more socially constructed or an interaction of social and biological than we believe and that religious and cultural teachings sustain unfair and harmful hierarchies but because paull commits to this being a story about bees a lot of people are left wanting more clear and direct parallels they throw up their hands and say just use humans to make your point and miss that paull is using human themes to tell a captivating story about bees not the other way around this brings us to the second criticism people don't like her anthropomorphization is that a word of bees as much as the rabbits in watership down well boo fucking hoo watership down is the most beautifully balanced anthropomorphic novel ever written but the job is much easier with rabbits animals that are modestly similar to humans bees are completely alien and yet also one of the closest animals to humans in their ability to communicate and coordinate complex work so paull is left with the daunting task of anthropomorphizing an animal that is almost unbelievable from the start that said at times the humanness of the bees seems inconsistent and early on this can be a bit annoying as the reader is struggling to get their bearings in the alien world of the hive what you you mean by hands they use cups they know what metal and glass and machines are why are the spiders fucking mystics the book isn't perfect in this respect but the annoyance drops away as you become invested in the story despite its short comings the bees remains a fascinating pairing of a rich alien world with human concerns about power religion duty love and finding meaning in a life where death is right around the corner the bees is not as profound and handmaid's tale and it doesn't capture your heart like watership down so it's not a book you clutch to your chest when you finish and whisper wow to the empty room but it's an innovative and captivating story and flora 717 is a great main character who successfully carries the reader through a complex and alien world brilliant choice to make flora both ignorant about the ways of the hive yet exposed to all facets of hive life so we can learn along with her you read this story and you love and hate bees and wasps and spiders and flies to a lesser extent you worry about the fate of the hive you mourn deaths and bristle at injustice not because the bees are stand ins for people but because you care about the bees that seems like a significant accomplishment considering that paull confronts the brevity of bee life head on i started out thinking this was a 3 star story and by the end it felt like a 5 star story paull won me over a solid 7 5 10 on the can't put it down scale it's relatively short with short chapters that pull you along a consistent pov focused on flora 717 adds to the enjoyment and emotional impact of the book recommended broadly but particularly to people who have diverse tastes in literature and can be patient with a novel that doesn't immediately fall into any one category slight spoiler about the general arc of the book but not really to follow it's really about the africanization of bee populations in the america's right like how domestication of european bees has led them to be sickly and unable to cope with the stresses of their environment and the introduction of aggressive and powerful wild bees from africa may be the key to saving bee populations right i think the fact that it tells a meaningful story about the actual bee world adds another layer to this novel and makes it even more impressive bees

raw_text.1277: into a honeybee hive we go a gorgeous tale of a caste society told through the eyes of a singular honeybee born into the lowly sanitation kin flora 717 is distinct from her kin and through her interactions with other classes we are are provided with a view into most activities in a hive from complex work religious and social structures to attacks by myriad predators to the death of the queen flora shows us what it takes to survive and persevere
raw_text.1278: the concept for this book was interesting as was the way the author handled the creation of characters that were at the same time completely alien while also somehow familiar writing from the perspective of a bee within a hive and adding in the human details imagined around the observations of the complex details in the life of a hive that we have provided food for thought while reading the book not everything will be explained just as not everything is ever explained in life this was very much a science fiction novel just on a scale we perhaps have overlooked or rarely consider to be science fiction this takes science and spins a fictional story within it and uses some of the classic themes seen in more traditional science fiction there were times where it felt a bit forced in order to continue the concept or further the idea but based on the idea behind the book it was understandable also some of the ideas didn't always seem to have been fully fleshed out or work well within the contexts it didn't always flow and there were sometimes where i had to push to keep reading there seemed to be a larger message or metaphor that was implied especially considering the first and last chapters but it wasn't really clear to me except to see the parallels of false causality in our lives and also the rituals that become religion when previously based on biology common sense or good practice
raw_text.1279: the bees is a book that you're either going to be into or you will dislike i was very afraid that i would fall into the dislike side but somehow i ended up really loving this tale of a lowly sanitation worker flora 717 the words and the prose are candy covered and edible - there is a sort of 'night circus' twinge to it but we focus on one character and her full life from her birth to her end flora 717 starts out her life being experimented on by the wiser sage bees and she's placed in the nursery to help with the babies her devotion is absolute to her hive her sisters and above all the queen mother we follow her as we go through her months of life connecting with certain bees as she has adventures like fighting a wasp's nest to nearly dying at an electric pole through it all her love remains steady towards her kin and she's devoted and loyal to the queen paull uses the most wonderful descriptions of things like their daily devotion the rapture they feel at the queen's love and their food of honey cakes and pollen bread i can only imagine the amount of research this book took as paull humanizes the bees and their life cycle introducing you to biological facts painted as "prophecies" and "ancient customs" i very much enjoyed it and i might even say that since i combined the audio and the physical book my enjoyment grew even more as the narrator orlagh cassidy was spectacular i recommend this if you enjoy a sort of adult fantasy dystopian esque literary fiction

to whether the novel has a story to tell about the human condition it's the bees knees #thebees by @lalinepaull in concept this is an adventurous novel which makes it a challenge to review it's fiction but it's clear that paull has done a lot of research into the subject matter so it's almost a dramatisation of biological science just as so many early sf novels were a dramatisation of the science of space flight the question is whether it succeeds as fiction in its own right this boils down to whether the novel has a story to tell about the human condition if we can't see humanity through the lens of the bees whether it's in the personalities of flora or sir linden or the queen or any of the others then the book fails the book had many resonances for me the whole background of a stratified hierarchical society calls to mind orwell's 1984 etc and the works of solzhenitsyn it also recalled the strict hierachies of the mediaeval monastic orders it brings out the very human struggling for power the politicking that opposes ordinary people attempting to better themselves to fulfil their potential or just to do the right thing in a tight spot curiously it also resonates with the stage i was reminded of capek's the insect play which uses an insect metaphor for its satire and because of the dance aspect i could also imagine that it would translate well into a ballet yes really in term of plot i don't think it held too many surprises but that's not a bad thing in this case the life of an insect is well mapped out after all and having read about insects from boyhood to the present day it all rang true even the twist every novel should take you on a journey perhaps to somewhere you've never been or perhaps to somewhere familiar but by a different route maybe faster maybe slower some novels take you to an amusement park to disneyland they try to hide the destination and surprise you like a stage magician this novel takes you round the science museum the guide doesn't hurry you she lets you wander round peer closely at the exhibits and look deep inside them even into their souls there's your answer you do indeed get to see inside the souls and see all too clearly those resonances of the human condition rather than repeat myself i'll direct you to my interim posts http williamcampbellpowell booklike http williamcampbellpowell booklike the ending raw_text.1286: i wasn't sure what to make of this book at first the difficulty of writing and reading from such an alien perspective and the inevitable compromises involved the faux medievalised language and cultural structure the hypnotic steady slowness of the plot but in the end it almost entirely won me over why first because the bees is engaged with themes of climate change and with gender politics with questions of class and privilege and power with equality and difference second because that alienating perspective while always a conceit does an exciting job of reflecting our own tired and brown world back at us the way we treat our planet is narrowing our lives just as much as the bees' only the impact isn't felt in such a catastrophically short space of time thirdly because of the way in which the book manages to so skillfully manipulate the drama of 'a year in the life of a beehive' a tough thing to do finally because there is such an enormous amount of heart in laline paull's novel yes the book's protagonist flora 717 is a lot of a mary sue but at the same time i can't help but be lifted by the determination of her duty her care and respect for her sisters and the way that her overwhelming love of her people is purely that and not accompanied by any bigotry or hatred of others i had a little tear in my eye at the end

raw_text.1331: the bees tells the story of an eventful year in a honeybee hive as flora 717 is born with an unusual combination of abilities it's about motherhood and sisterhood and how power corrupts it took me a while to get into but paull excellently portrays the control of the hive by the queen's pheromones as a quasi religious system she also manages to capture personalities of bees with different roles the creepy indistinguishable priestesses the carers who nurse the larvae the individualistic foragers and the amusingly entitled and self absorbed drones the novel failed as an allegory for me as human nature is just so different from bee nature i can't imagine that level of self abnegation ever being achieved in human society and it is difficult to even come close to it except by fear and tyranny however it taught me a lot about a fascinating insect and was an enjoyable read
raw_text.1332: this delightful book is a page turner as full of suspense as any thriller and i was unable to put it down once i started to get involved i loved it and had great pleasure reading it it follows the life of an unusual bee flora 717 as a series of perfectly believable adventures takes her into every aspect of the hive from the most menial sanitation tasks to the most challenging battles with mortal enemies outside and within it does allow the bees and other creatures to communicate in language and to engage in behaviour that might be considered anthropomorphic yet it does not turn them into little humans but rather finds ways to portray how bees might experience their very distinctive world communicating through chemicals as well as dance sharing a collective hive mind and maintaining a complex web of relationships that resemble a caste system there are some magical elements but nothing that really steps very far outside the laws of physics as long as you will tolerate some nefarious transactions with spiders and wasps actually i am not so willing too concede much intelligence to spiders or even wasps but by and large it seems to me that we have a fairly intelligent description of the way bees might function it is no bad thing to describe this through a gripping adventure story since it is becoming rather urgent for humanity to wake up to the ecological importance of bees and other insects and the dreadful consequences of the harm we do with chemical pollution and habitat destruction we seem too stupid as a species or too viciously selfish as a food industry to react to scientific reports or political writing on the lines of silent spring so maybe fiction could help to agitate public opinion fear not there is nothing overtly didactic or political about the way this story is told i can see why comparison might be drawn with george orwell or margaret atwood for example but i personally did not read this as a dystopia or even an allegory it is not like animal farm for instance if humans try to organise society along the lines of a bee hive or an ant colony that would of course be disturbing but i think it would be a bit odd to get concerned about the lack of democracy or individual freedom in the collective lives of a bee hive or an ant colony no the thing is to appreciate how they do live which is one of the many great wonders of our natural world i just hope nobody from the beekepers association http www bbka org uk pops up to tell me this book has made any important mistakes about the behaviour of bees confession time i bought this for my daughter as a birthday present and she has yet to get her hands on it

raw_text.1384: this is an incredible book i started a dog's purpose and didn't make it past the 4th chapter i couldn't accept the idea that dogs could talk and write books and even if they could butt sniffing didn't seem like a very interesting subject to talk and write about so when i started the bees and encountered the talking bees on the first page i groaned but gradually i got sucked into the story and what a story it is ok let's get the suspend disbelief thing out of the way first yes you've got to be able to do it and it's not just the talking thinking planning communicating but also little details like tiny handles on the doors in the hives and tiny brooms for cleaning the floor but the most amazing thing about this book is that all the impossible bee feats that you think are impossible like the way they kill wasps or embalm a mouse or communicate via scent turn out to be absolutely true the reason this story is so interesting is that from the research i've done since reading the book every part of it is absolutely true ok i'm not sure about the motives behind the actions but what the bees do largely happens and i'm not sure the caste system is enforced as in the book but the idea that different bees have different jobs to do is largely true ok i'm pretty sure the interaction and dialog between bees and spiders and bees and wasps is largely fictional the story follows the life of one spunky bee and by the end you'll be cheering for her through all her trials and adventure along the way the author covers all the interesting things bees do like their weird sex life and gender discrimination unlike the dog book at one point i actually felt like i was a bee in the hive worrying whether our food was sufficient to make it through the winter some of the scenes don't really advance the plot but are just bee activities from the bees point of view like encountering a cell tower and its strange magnetic pulsations one thing i think you'll feel is that the author is having a rollicking great time writing this book i don't think that comes through very often for novels it's like if the author is having such a great time you probably will too a lot is made of the religious aspects of the book like it's some deep allegory on organized religion i don't think so i think it's just the way bees are and the author had fun with it for example the bees go to devotion and say the queen's prayer our mother who art hallowed be her womb i think this is just fun bees do worship their queen at one point some insects are accusing other insects of being dirty apists i think the author is just enjoying the pun more than trying to say anything deeper the book is actually pretty funny at times one last note i listened to the audio book the reader was incredible it's one thing for a reader to do different human accents but this reader had appropriate different voices for all kinds of insects really amazing and effective it's one of those books you listen to and wonder if it would have been as good if you read it on paper

raw_text.1393: this book is very very original it is written from the point of view of a bee named flora and the book presents a dystopian and almost totalitarian society flora doesn't seem to think too many things -- she doesn't dwell on her situation or her surroundings and her actions are described more often than her thoughts are and yet she is so vivid to the reader we come to understand who she is and what she wants and we come to understand her purpose in this novel laline has done a fantastic job of creating a fleshed out three dimensional character within this dystopian and extremely unique environment for the first fifty pages i almost felt like i was reading another language there are specific terms for bees within each level of 'society' in their hive and their life and their actions and their 'work' has been described with a specific terminology it does take a bit of getting used to -- the writing style is very descriptive the author goes into great detail about flora's world and what she sees in that world since this entire novel is written from the point of view of a bee the reader has to adapt to what their threats are and thus what the 'tension' is in the book bees fear wasps and spiders and rain naturally readers don't find those as threatening but we are forced to imagine the situation from flora's point of view laline must have done a fair bit of research before writing this novel because there are a lot to things to be learnt from the day to day life presented to us readers bees do dance to communicate and the different 'work' that is performed in a hive is true to reality however i do think this novel would've been better had it of been shorter it's about 100 150 pages too long by the end i just wanted to finish it i've read a lot of reviews where readers felt the story dragged on and it got monotonous and that the bees would've been better as a novella or short story i agree i would've liked to have seen this cut down but it is fascinating and it is extremely well written and it's a great piece of literary fiction http jessjustreads com
raw_text.1394: the bees was probably better in conception than in execution and that's why i enjoyed the first half most where we get to be introduced to the hive system and the interesting way it's been anthropomorphised whilst still retaining its apine identity it was a fun idea to use lots of analogies to religion to make the society relatable and the originality and fantastical novelty of the setting which another reviewer aptly compared to science fiction is the best thing about the book i would have liked some loose ends tied up especially what we're supposed to make of the spider's prophecy that doesn't appear to come true in any way i can tell and what the cause of the sickness is is it just chance is it connected to the pollution my biggest gripe about it is that the main character flora 717 is pretty much a superbee compared to all the others and it's not explained though thankfully in the acknowledgments the author does at least point out that bees have been known to do parthenogenesis this had been bugging me throughout because we are told that sex results in fertility but the fertile flora never has sex i would instantly recommend this to any bee enthusiasts themes include pollution climate change parenthood and pollinating insects that buzz

raw_text.1405: review posted on reading lark 6 27 14 http readinglark blogspot com 2014 this one was an unrequested gift from the publisher i don't always have time to work those beauties in quickly but this one called to me so i did my best to squeeze it in as soon as i possibly could the bees was supposed to be the handmaid's tale meets the hunger games while i haven't read the handmaid's tale i love the hunger games i decided something compared to a beloved series with insects as the characters was something i needed to read i also expect that this one will also conjure memories of animal farm for many readers the bees is a deviation from my standard reading fare i don't often read adult literary fiction most of the adult titles i read are historical fiction but i felt like i needed to push outside of my comfort zone i did find that i couldn't be lazy with this one there is so much going on and so many details to remember that you can't just glide pleasurably through this novel it demands your attention from moment one the novel opens with the birth of flora 717 a bee who is destined to be a sanitation worker the social structure of the bees brought to mind the caste system of india bees are born into specific roles change is an abnormality that is not allowed to flourish interaction between the bees is also determined by the hive's social hierarchy flora 717 immediately shows characteristics that set her apart from her kin she becomes a symbol for change throughout the novel as she breaks all the molds and rules of the hive i was in awe of her resilience and courage she chose to stand up for herself and those she loved even when it meant a certain death i wasn't sure how i would enjoy a novel in which the main characters were bees but i found that the author did a beautiful job of pulling me into this world and helping me visualize life in the hive the beauty of this life is balanced by some gruesome moments and lack of freedom as i read i searched for parallels between flora's world and human society gender inequality and diversity were elements that continued to crop up for me overall i found this to be a novel that was both unique and thought provoking i loved watching flora adapt and strive to do her best for the hive it was apparent that laline paull had done a vast amount of research and observation to make this novel feel authentic i doubt i will ever be able to look at a bee without thinking of flora and her sisters one last gripe there were some moments that i wish had moved along a bit faster favorite thing about this book i loved getting to explore the hive and its social structure first sentence the old orchard stood besieged favorite character flora 717least favorite character sister sage

raw_text.1417: this review is also posted at http time2tome wordpress com 2014 1 2 5 starsi began laline paull's the bees with good feelings towards bees i mean i wasn't ready to be snuggle buddies with a hive but i adore honey so i was willing to spread the love to the honey makers now well i've probably developed apiphobia let's start at the literal beginning - flora 717 being born grotesquely large and deformed into the lowest caste in the hive the sanitation bees sanitation is responsible for removing the dead and other waste and its members are considered to be dumb in both senses of the term all bees are expected above all to be dutiful and obedient to their hive including by following the cardinal rule that no one but the queen bee may breed because of flora's biological differences and innate curiosity a sage priestess decides to use her for a series of experiments elevating flora first to the nursery where she demonstrates the rare ability to feed the offspring and then to forager status allowing her to fly free and gather food for the family however her actions soon stray into sedition as she inadvertently challenges the status quo by proving to be more fertile than the queen her growing maternal instincts battle with her socialized desire to serve her society as she struggles to discover how to protect both her child and her hive from the evil within and without flora is the worst and therefore i frequently amused my roommate with vehement exclamations wishing for her imminent demise she possesses the simultaneous and awkward mix of too much intelligence and too little questioning everything and not exactly knowing when to shut up though thankfully her judgement improves over the course of the book sadly without her there would be no plot because she was the one exploring the hive and overthrowing the rigidly hierarchical system - what can i say guess i'm not a rebel her short sighted ignorance frustrated rather than incited sympathy from me especially as her ill conceived actions kept endangering her fellow bees including that of her own caste whom she behaved snobbishly toward she was generally one selfish little bee otch most of the supporting cast were only vaguely sketched out so it was difficult to know them as individuals rather than the collective my favorite characters appeared on page only briefly including a sweet fly that sacrificed himself for flora the devious fortune telling spiders and the elderly gentleman who "owns" the hive and serves as a rare human intrusion into hive world the drones were debatably the highlight adding a welcomed humorous element with their narcissistic affectations and dialogue dripping with sexual innuendo - at least until their macabre death sequence may they rest in...pieces... i'm still unsure what was truth and what was fiction about bees which could be considered the mark of a good writer but in actuality annoyed me for example how badly are the bees affected by the removal of honey does bee mating work as she posited a question i never thought i'd ask in general while paull's plot was wildly innovative her world building was imbalanced pivotal points went unexplained from the sages' schemes and religious authority to the queen's communication and memory retention capabilities and most irritatingly flora's pregnancy the writing overall tended towards the poetic favoring style over substance this book is billed as the handmaid's tale meets the hunger games but perhaps more accurately can be considered the end result of quentin tarentino and george orwell teaming up to revamp charlotte's web as i mentioned initially i'm currently still traumatized from the experience of reading this i'll certainly never forget this book as it is one of the scariest tales i've read perhaps ever i'm torn on the rating because it was memorable and creative but i didn't particularly enjoy the experience of reading it

raw_text.1455: the bees follows the life of flora 717 a sanitation worker bee within her orchard hive when she emerges her hive is in a time of stress with their source of nectar threatened by weather and pesticides she is not like other bees and rises above her station to serve her hive with strength and perseverance i found the look into the bee colony and hive mind alien and fascinating we are able to experience the strict rules and hierarchy of the hive that keeps individual identity as secondary to the well being of the whole and ultimately the queen she is both the galvanizing force and source of the hive's health and life the bee's eye view brings a whole new perspective on the relationship between the natural and man made world it brings to mind many things that face every living thing in this world - how do you deal with adverse conditions and learn to adapt and thrive when forced to take an unknown path into the future

raw_text.1457: laline paull's interesting and ambitious first novel "the bees " follows worker bee flora 717 a sanitation worker born into the lowest caste of a large beehive it is the job of the floras to collect the bodies of dead bees and dispose of them to sweep the gutters flora 717 like her fellow bee sisters is able to understand what her fellow bees are thinking through scent and vibration and touch however unlike her flora sisters within her social class flora 717 is prone to speech and capable of quick thinking and her actions cause her to be noticed by the ruling caste and singled out for duty in different parts of the hive allowing the reader to observe bee activities in all parts of the hive troubled times have fallen on the hive with nearby fields of flowers coated with bee killing substances requiring foragers to travel longer and longer distances in search of pollen and despite her birth status flora is eventually promoted to being a forager the descriptions of her first flights as well as the subsequent dances at which the bees share the information from their flower seeking journeys are incredibly vivid for the first half of the book i questioned the accuracy of many of the bee behaviors but by the end i was willing to suspend any skepticism and enjoy the story which includes the detailed workings of a hive of bees but is more an exploration of the repressed cult like politics of the hive the first commandment of the hive is to "accept obey and serve" flora is devoted to serving her queen but then biology intervenes and she produces an egg that she must then hide as egg laying is reserved for the queen abiding to this rule is monitored by fertility police that inspect eggs and offspring to be sure they are the queen's offspring and also inspect worker bees for signs of having given birth flora 717's feelings for her offspring are wholly separate from her love for the queen and she struggles with her biological urge to protect her baby and her need to serve the hive as an analogy for a class bound society in which differences are punished the book succeeds at least partially more could be made of the associations to human society and the reader's connection to flora as a heroine despite this and despite the fact that the the book's ending is visible long before the final scene the story is overall quite compelling there are plot points that were confusing and unresolved and the pace is uneven in parts although environmental issues are hinted at i felt like the signs and causes of ecosystem destruction should have been more developed and incorporated into the story

raw_text.1525: you've never been inside a hive before have you of course not i don't think anybody has ever written a book possibly apart from a picture book written from the perspective of the bee read laline paull's debut and you might feel you've visited one i was very impressed with this book my cover is stunning some versions seem to differ yellow hexagons with the hive motto on it accept obey serve this is one of the things we are all taught about bees as children they each have their own role to play in the hive and laline paull plays with this idea to create a world set at the insect eye level did you ever see the woody allen film ostensibly for children antz a comedy about a neurotic ant who didn't feel appreciated as an individual this book looks at conformity individuality and co operation in a much more serious way and you feel that from the beginning flora 717 is born to be a worker she emerges from her egg with this knowledge as part of her hive she is also born with knowledge of her ever loving mother the queen bee who is devoutly worshipped by all her children each of whom has a closely policed and separate role to play in the efficient running of their home but flora immediately shows herself to be unique able to talk unlike the other workers she is moved to areas of the hive a worker would not otherwise have access to and thus we are also granted access to the workings of the hive however the hive is nesting a secret one which threatens to destroy flora's swarm i adored the bee's point of view writing i don't think you have to be a fan of natural history to enjoy this but i certainly finished and immediately went online to look at how much of the book is based on real bee behaviour and it looks like laline paull really did her homework it's a real eye opener and fascinating and not just the biology but a great story set over the course of a year in the life of one hive flora rather conveniently but usefully for the book is moved around the hive in various roles meeting higher up priestesses bees who serve the queen directly the queen herself and in the book's few comedic scenes the male drones i loved the drones when we meet the males it's like the opening scene of romeo and juliet with male posturing sexual innuendo and high jinx one drone repeatedly crosses paths with flora and through linden we also get to learn about the males' role in hive life and continuity and we also get the novel's one light touch at a romantic subplot which of course is a little too anthropomorphic bees don't fall in love paull mostly treads the line of reality and fantasy carefully for of course for the book to work we have to have bees communicating and speaking to us in terms we can understand i like the way paull does this the only time i felt she went too far was in having a cleaner bee using implements to clean that was the only time it jarred with me the publishers have compared the bees to several other famous books i've already mentioned two of my own i would agree that there are shades of the handmaid's tale in paull's book the idea of conformity and subservience being similiar in the two i would disagree most strongly with any likeness to the hunger games however this to me is jumping on the bandwagon and i don't feel this book needs to do that it can stand on its own merits the world of flora's hive is nothing like that of katniss's district 12 there are battles but all are of natural origin wasp attack spiders some within the hive that's not to say fans of the hunger games won't like this flora is brave determined and smart and there is more action that you might be expecting i would also say there are similarities to tarka the otter on the natural history theme both in terms of the animal's eye view and the structure and ultimate arc of the story i'm not one for religious stories and themes but i did like the way paull used religious fervour like 1984's devotion to big brother if i can make another comparison as a form of control and unity between the bees they worship their mother they each connect to her regularly and strive to protect her and feed her she is the centre of their world and their hive and that's also the crux of the story i'm really glad i gave this a read every time i see a bee now as i write spring has started and bees are all on the move again i think of flora hunting for nectar and think of what she would see if she came across me i loved reading about her world loved the idea loved playwright paull's writing and plot hope she has another unique idea for her next book as i'll be watching out for it review of a lovereading co uk advance copy

raw_text.1532: well this is an interesting one honestly i'd rather have given it 3 1 2 stars but goodreads doesn't allow for that the bees is about well bees the cover copy describes it as the handmaid's tale meets the hunger games but i think it has a little more in common with watership down it's xenofiction meaning the entire story is told from the pov of non human protagonists which is fine except the book can't seem to decide if it's about semi realistic honeybees given a human like pov the way rabbits are treated in watership down or straight up fantasy there's a setup involving different kinds of worker bees having a certain hierarchy depending on their lineage as i understand it this isn't realistic bee behavior a worker bee will perform most of the duties of the hive throughout her life i guess this is where the hunger games stuff comes in flora 717 is born unique more intelligent and bigger than the sanitation worker bees of her caste for reasons never clearly explained despite the fact that the hive authorities are vigilant in culling bees who show signs of mutations she's allowed to live and ends up performing most of the hive duties in an exceptional way she's just a better bee i guess maybe a positive mutation she's also a laying worker and inasmuch as this book really has a plot that would be the crux of the conflict worker bees are forbidden from laying eggs and flora 717 doesn't set out to break the rules it's just that her body isn't listening to her actually that's a bit of an issue i have for about 3 4 of the book flora doesn't really make major decisions or go through much character development things just happen to her it makes for a nice exploration of her world and all but it seems like she's just drifting through the plot and not much is at stake the other characters aren't really all that noteworthy other than sir linden the only drone bee to really undergo any character development honeybees being honeybees their lives are short and often come to violent ends as a result a lot of the side characters die there is a lot of death in this book understandably the biggest issue i had with this book is that it can't quite decide on its premise and keeps drifting into the outright fantastical the bees are at times a little too anthropomorphic i can buy the bees having a kind of bee religion centering around the queen but when they start chanting a prayer that's literally a version of our father with the words changed around it makes the metaphor a little too ham handed and obvious and ruins the immersion there's a scene early on where the bees are described as serving cakes and pouring drinks from silver pitchers alongside descriptions of them well eating the way bees eat the male bees decorate their puffs with pomade if these were animal people like in the redwall books those little details would be fine but here they feel out of place giving the bees human like characteristics is one thing but slipping in and out of fantasy elements is another entirely as a result certain passages just end up unintentionally funny that said the prose is lovely vivid and descriptive and the world laline paull creates is a really interesting one the way bees communicate through scent and dance is brought to life in a fascinating way i feel like the book is at its best when it describes the ways bees are kind of alien to us rather than trying to draw forced allegorical comparisons to human societies even some of the fantastical elements are pretty neat stories told through hive memory soothsaying spiders i probably would have rated this book a little lower were it not for the last 1 3 to 1 4 of the book here the story finally picks up pace the various narrative threads start to finally come together the worldbuilding stops feeling quite so haphazard flora starts to finally stand out as a character instead of just a viewpoint for the reader and the whole thing ends in a very satisfying manner do i recommend the book if you're in for something unusual and don't mind some unintentional silliness sure give it a look it's not like there are too many other novels about honeybees out there

raw_text.1580: firstly this isn't really fantasy dystopia it's fantastical but the book has very little in common with something like the handmaid's tale which the cover compares it to it also uses the word innovative which is the least appropriate word to describe any work of fiction more than anything the bees made me think of the film antz with a curious blend of biological reality and anthropomorphism 'fertility police' measure new bees with callipers pollen is baked into bread and honey is served in cups it's extremely jarring at first and took a while for me to ease into the book as a whole is dazzlingly imaginative but still at its best when sticking close to the truth for example the descriptions of the bees gathering nectar and pollen from flowers my main problem with the book however was less the anthropomorphism and more the mary sue protagonist flora 717 is born into the lowest rank within the hive yet through some genetic anomaly is able to perform and excel at any biological role she tries her hand at it was just a bit boring there was an utter inevitability to the story the author also appeared to alter her own world rules sometimes for example when the time to hibernate for winter comes flora is terrified of dreaming of her transgressions and betraying herself to her entire hive because she cannot control what she dreams yet when she does join her sisters in sleep there is no issue and indeed it is never alluded to again i also agree with another reviewer in that some physical aspects of the hive are poorly written such that the reader struggles to know whether they should be imagining a completely fantastical place of light open corridors and hallways or dark crowded spaces as hives must be in reality all this said the bees is readable and i got through it quickly hence why i'd give this 3 5 rather than 3 on amazon if i could my eyes watered during the last few pages and after i'd finished and i saw a jar of honey sitting in my cupboard i felt a vague sense of guilt i also commend the author for the environmental streak in the story in which pesticides poison and plants are lost to green deserts i didn't try to raw_text.1608: you know how when you finish a book and want so desperately to sit down over tea with the author and discuss well life after completing laline paull's the bees oh boy did i have questions while it took me a long time to get through the book no fault of the author this past may life just got in the way i was totally engrossed in every single page initially i didn't understand the intense pull this book had but after some time i soon realized that i was holding an intricate puzzle that i so desperately wanted to solve i'm still trying to put the pieces together while paull paints a beautifully vivid and detailed world of the hive and its occupants this book is not just about bees flora holds a mirror up to human society and dares them to look away it has already been compared to animal farm and i suspect it will eventually make its way into middle and high school classrooms however i think it's worth examining the feminist issues paull raises throughout bees there were times when the reading made me uncomfortable where i questioned exactly what the author was trying to convey at times i wondered if she indeed loved her heroine as flora's decisions were both marred by bravery and cowardice it's clear that the author thoroughly researched her subject matter and at times i found myself frustrated wishing i had paid more attention in science class this is a book i will have to read again with pen in hand and a group of friends at the ready to discuss argue and question flora's purpose in her society while skirting around our own perplexities come awards time i would not be surprised to see the bees making a few short lists this story would also translate beautifully to the big screen however it will take someone willing to push technology a bit further as the production would need to be as real and complex as its source matter i also suspect that over time and a few more readings my 4 star rating will be off the charts

raw_text.1633: i love bees and this is perhaps the most interesting and imaginative book about bees that i've ever read which is saying a lot it takes place in the hive itself and the protagonist is flora 717 a lowly worker bee who struggles with two opposing and all consuming forces her love for her queen and her love for the hive as a whole i was immediately taken by the concept and for the most part the execution of this story while some of the plot points were predictable the ending took me by surprise in a good way i loved seeing the world from flora's point of view entering the hive and exploring the tunnels of comb seeing how the author laline paull created a complex world and society that springs from the actual world of a hive was fascinating and really really fun that said as a beekeeper some of the details were a little hard to swallow yet even in the moments where i paused in my reading and thought wait a minute that can't but what about i was pulled back in a second later because the story was just so good flora is a great character and the fact that she is a bee makes her that much more memorable i've seen this book compared to the handmaid's tale which i reread last year i don't think the books have that much in common i didn't read the bees as a story about an individual trapped by a dystopian society where women are valued only for the reproductive abilities while reproduction is a central theme in the bees and a huge source of conflict it's treated much differently to me the bees is about an individual who is willing to sacrifice anything and everything from what she loves and the struggle to find and then accept what that thing is also this book has the greatest cover off all time

raw_text.1639: accept obey and serve a flora may not make wax for she is impure nor work with propolis for she is clumsy nor may she ever forage for she has no taste but only may she clean and all may command her labour flora 717 is one such flora kin bee deemed as the lowest of the low within the hive hierarchy and only fit to carry her dead sister bees to the morgue or clean in sanitation in a community where only the queen may breed this novel follows flora's life from her hatching in the 'arrivals hall' as one by one she smashes each of the laws which determine her class and role often leading her into scrapes from which she must escape or risk death this novel is so well written and the language so lyrical that it was so easy to identify with flora 717 the author's bee eye view offering a different perspective on issues which affect our environment and wildlife such as insecticides and the effect that these chemicals can have on the production of honey and the survival of the bees suddenly other insects and birds become enemies even the slow slug and the wars fought between the bees and these predators as well as the 'civil wars' within the hive make this book a real page turner i was hooked and sacrificed many hours' sleep just to find out what was going to happen i'm glad that i read this book it is wonderful it's different but that is part of its charm and what makes it so memorable the characters may be bees but many of their issues have parallels in our human world class and power struggles attack deception working all hours in order to provide for families and the emotion of love and sacrifice a fantastic debut novel i don't think i will ever see bees in the same light again from now on

raw_text.1645: i think it's the mark of a truly thought provoking book when days later having long finished the book i still find myself mulling over the writing paull managed to accomplish the impossible and wrote about bees in a way that simultaneously emphasized their strange insect qualities and their human concerns using a structured hierarchy like a bee hive as a prism in order to examine the flaws in our human society and the extremes of power and religion was superbly clever and the world in which paull crafted was riveting and well thought out and well researched as i looked up a lot of the plot points from the book and found out that they actually occurred in nature as well but i'm not really sure if in the end i actually enjoyed the book on a visceral emotional level i thought it was interesting and finished the book because of its quick pace and well written prose but i don't think i ever became emotionally invested in flora the main character or other concerns of the plot and the one romantic relationship hinted at towards the end was a little clumsily shoe horned in and felt almost irrelevant so all in all interesting thoughtful well plotted and written but perhaps lacks a certain emotional appeal
