the origin of the story on her web site a beekeeper friend of mine died far too young in the immediate aftermath of her death i began reading about the bees she loved so much very quickly i realized i was exploring the most extraordinary ancient society that was like a hall of mirrors to our own some things very similar others a complete inversion whilst more were fantastically alien and amazing the more i read the more i wanted to find out but when i learned about the phenomenon of the laying worker i became incredibly excited by the huge dramatic potential of that situation her feeling of loss is very much present here bees are not the longest lived creatures on the planet and more than a few see their end here but there is another element as well from a recent interview posted here on goodreads becoming a mother changed me and made me stronger--but evolution is never easy i didn't write flora from an intellectual perspective but in a very visceral way motherhood made me a more passionate person--or allowed me to express that innate side of myself much more so perhaps that's why flora works as a character there's primal truth in her motivation she accepts her life one way but then a forbidden force takes possession of her called love religious nomenclature permeates the tale the queen is not only a temporal ruler but is considered divine as well this is helped along by her ability to produce pheromones in vast quantity that can soothe her hive family there are sacraments in this world a catechism rituals prayers some of which will sound familiar there are also some virgin births and what would religion be without a little human sacrifice or in this case bee sacrifice it is a place in which religion is joined to politics to generate orwellian mantras like accept obey serve desire is sin idleness is sin from death comes life eternal and the like and of course there is some orwellian behavior life is held cheaply particularly for those not of the favored groups and the jack booted police that enforce the rules are definitely a buzzkill the death penalty is more the norm than the exception and it is often applied immediately and energetically western honey beeflora's explorations of the world are entire adventures on their own as she encounters not only adversaries like wasps spiders and crows but man made hazards as well on the other hand she experiences the longing of the flowers and the expanded internal horizons that result from expanding one's horizons externally she has a particular longing of her own which fires the engines of her determination the bees is a fast paced engaging invigorating tale that will have you flipping pages faster than a forager's wings you will come away not only with the warm feeling of having shared a remarkable journey but will find yourself eager to learn more about our buzzy brethren well except for nicolas cage and you might even find yourself tempted to get up and do a waggle dance extra stufflinks to the author's personal twitter and fb pagesin paull's site there is a photo of a minoan palace map that informed her hive layout worth a look this month's may 2014 gr newsletter features a brief interview with paullthat buzzing in your ear might be more cause for concern that you'd realized new project aims to upload a honey bee's brain into a flying insectobot by 2015an item i came across on a reason why bee population is in decline we may have figured out what's killing the bees
raw_text.2101: this is a lovely and original imaginative novel do not expect the bees to be either dry or cutesy it is not remotely either one i found myself caring about flora the bee who is the heroine and center of the story and engrossed with the tale of her surprising twists of identity and mission not knowing that much about bees and the structure of their hive and lives i cannot speak to the accuracy of the world that paull builds beneath the fictions of their speaking and emoting like humans but it is certainly coherent and convincing there are many themes running through the novel including the environmental destruction that threatens her hive as our honey bees are really and seriously threatened yet the end is hopeful and moving highly recommended
raw_text.2102: i cannot actually decide whether i like the bees or not yes the fact that i was motivated enough to finish it in 4 days shows that this book is able to offer something different into the almost saturated dystopian genre marketplace and is written in a way that creates some suspense and page turn ability however my biggest problem with the book is its inconsistencies in its writing the book began transporting the reader into a captivating world of bees anthropomorphising hive life in an intriguing and genuinely poetic way but around halfway through the book the writing seemed to lose some of its literary flare buzzing around on various tangents to progress the story in ways that weren't necessarily engaging for the reader i found my investment in flora seemed to dwindle throughout the novel caring less and less for the decisions she was making and focussing more and more on the slightly strange and sometimes weird language and descriptions being used by the author at times i felt myself a little disgusted by some of the things that were being written particularly the graphic nature in which the bees were 'purged' during this story their bodies being torn from their thoraxes and injected with poison not to mention the cult ish life the bees live within the hive full of rich descriptions of their devotional obsession with the queen bee and intricate details about their mating patterns and behaviours the word unnecessary springs to mind nonetheless even with the flaws discussed above there are many sections of this book that are beautifully written i would recommend it to others just for the different style that it offers watership down is one of my favourite books and no the bees does not compare some people have drawn similarities between them but what it does do is transport the reader into a world of animal adventure that we have not experienced before the ending was a let down it felt rushed unnecessary and just too simple but i think on the whole it is worth a read if you are looking for a book that isn't run of the mill

raw_text.2122: there are quite a few books out there that use an animal hierarchy and social structure to make commentary about human society watership down is the most well known of course a story about rabbits that can speak with each other and we follow these rabbits through their trials and tribulations sometimes involving humans sometimes not but the bees is a little bit different than reading other books about anthropomorphic creatures because unlike these other books we aren't dealing with animals we can truly relate to watership down dealt with rabbits and then other books of its like have dealt with wolves the sight or deer firebringer and let's be real most of the novels like this are about mammals warm fluffy mammals who are cute and who remind us most of our beloved pets animals we can relate to because they have so many similarities to humans in their behaviours this book is about bees insects are very foreign to us and frankly many people are frightened of insects especially bees and use the word bee interchangeably with wasp and hornet bees have fascinated me for a while now but most people aren't of that opinion so in that way the bees is unique instead of seeing it through the lens of a david attenborough special and i don't know about you guys but i miss a lot of valuable information in there because i'm desperately afraid of spiders and must skip through any scene that looks like one might appear we are in the hive understanding how this alien culture works bees unlike many animals have a hive mind and when seeing it from the perspective of a bee and not just looking down into a hive as an outsider it reads a lot like a dystopian society everyone lives for the love of the queen everyone is sorted based on job and class and has no name of their own the main character is not named flora she is flora 717 and like all bees with the name flora she is a sanitation worker although the society has no love for individuality being one of the hive does not mean that all bees are equal certain castes are above others and sanitation workers are the equivalent of unspeakables a parallel drawn clearly through the floras seeming inability to talk deformity is not tolerated any bee who defies or cannot properly serve the queen or who is too different or who does not follow the rigid religious scripture of the hive is eliminated it's a strict and very matriarchal world based very much on scent and feel generally i thought the author did a great job of showing the social structure of the bees in a way that as alien as it seemed it was also somewhat familiar and understandable she showed how death so much of a shock in our lives is an everyday occurrence with the bees as their life cycles are so much shorter she did well to tread the line of creating individuals while still adhering to the basic concept of a hive mind i also found that the environmental issues brought up especially the illness that strikes is very viscerally described and it's a jolt of fear to realise that what's happening in this book to these characters you've grown to like is actually happening at this very moment killing off many many to day workings of the hive and then a statement about pastries or hands pulls me right out of the text wondering what kind of book i'm reading why did there need to be mentions of bread is this a farmer's garden my other quibble was this how was flora able to conceive without any male partnership she lays three eggs and these all seem like the immaculate conception x3 but i'm not sure if that more gives it a religious cult feel bee hives are sometimes referred to as single organisms the individual bees acting as individual cells would in a body each with a different function each essential to each other and to the whole single bees know what they need to do either alone or with other bees to accomplish what needs to be done the hive in the bees however is presented as a caste system some bees more important or better than others some bees needing direction from other bees some bees dominating others also the author tries to characterize the bees with human emotions along with their natural bee tendencies i don't think bees get angry or resentful or even annoyed with other bees especially of their own hive i felt irritated that this hive was depicted other than efficient raw_text.2190: well there's been lots of buzz surrounding laline paull's debut novel the bees sorry couldn't resist and that buzz is well deserved flora 717 is born a sanitation worker in her hive the lowest of the low but flora 717 is an anomaly she can speak one of the sage priestesses take notice of her and flora is moved to the nursery to feed the young then against all odds she becomes a forager flying outside of the hive to find pollen and nectar to feed her hive she is brave and kind and tries to serve her queen and live by the hive's dictum 'accept obey and serve' but flora 717 has another ability one that goes against everything she has been taught from the moment she was born and it is this instinct that now changes not just flora's life but that of the queen and her hive now you might be saying to yourself really bees trust me you'll quickly become immersed in the life of the hive and truly invested in the character of flora 717 and as you read or listen you get caught up in her hopes and aspirations in the struggles of her and her kin and in the day to day life of the community and the hive's struggle to survive for there are predators humans make a brief appearance in the first and last chapters reminding us of the fragility of nature and the harm our chemicals wreak the details of the hive and of the lives of bees were both informative and fascinating did you know that it takes twelve bees their entire lives to gather enough nectar to make one teaspoon of honey the architectural structure of the hive was quite detailed and vividly drawn from the author i realized that the most astonishing creatures and events are happening everywhere it's just a question of scale whether we notice them or not paull's novel has definitely made me stop and take notice when i see bees busily buzzing in my flowerbeds then flying away makes you wonder i chose to listen to the bees orlagh cassidy was the reader she is a favourite narrator of mine but i am very used to listening to her reading thriller and action books i wondered how she would handle a distinctly different piece of work the answer is excellently cassidy's voice is unique with lots of hidden gravel and nuance she chose a voice for flora that i both enjoyed and suited the mental image i had created of flora cassidy interpreted the book very well using tone speed and inference to bring paull's prose to life there are some books i just know i have enjoyed more by listening rather than reading them the bees is one of those the bees has been aptly described as a combination watership down meets the handmaid's tale

raw_text.2192: i did not enjoy this book much at all this follows the life of flora 717 a worker bee in sanitation who we see from her emergence as an adult until her old age i can only describe this book as a bee thriller let's consider some general characteristics of a thriller from a readers' advisory standpoint fast paced story all about action check it felt like flora 717 just went from adventure to adventure with little character development happening wasp spider bunch of wasps serve the queen mouse etc etc etc professional details and jargon in this case bee work check loner hero who operates under his or her own moral code flora 717 pretty much defies all conventional bee life and does whatever she wants check view spoiler it's up to the hero to save the world check flora 717 gives birth to the next princess and leads her fellow bees to a new home hide spoiler i do not care for thrillers or allegory and the bees was a bizarre combination of both i didn't care for the writing style or the allusions to religion as some sort of fascist method to keep everybody in line maybe the gender stuff was a little interesting most of the bees are female but are constantly falling all over themselves to worship the male drones i appreciate the research that must have gone into this book as there were a lot of true details of bee life in this novel if anything it made me want to go watch a bee documentary

raw_text.2205: when i read the description of this book i was immediately intrigued a novel that takes place entirely from the perspective of a bee that was certainly different from anything else i'd been reading lately although there are sections of building stories that follow a bee as such i couldn't help but check it out and it turned out to be one of my favorite novels of the year so far the story follows sanitation worker flora 717 on her personal odyssey through the inner and outer workings of a colony of bees events push her from one faction to another as she learns all about the inner workings of her hive and the agendas that different groups harbor inside it as she does she also learns more and more about herself while many behaviors demonstrated are very clearly pure fiction it is hard not to feel like one is actually learning something about the bees one sees around one's neighborhood all the same it's also a novel about the effects of blind faith learning to understand the differences of those around you life under an oppressive regime and the lengths one will go to for love this is an absolutely beautiful book that will linger with you after it's done and have a marked change on the way you look at the insects that exist all around us

raw_text.2212: i was given this book in work to review and to be honest apart from seeing mercedes' review in her october wrap up i didn't know anything about it i consequently read a few reviews after receiving it and it was pegged as a cross between the handmaid's tale and the hunger games by several sites i haven't read atwood's novel but the bees promised to be an unusual take on the dystopian genre and i completely agree with the characters all being bees and the story mostly taking place within the hive it did take me a few chapters to get into it i don't know anything about bees and their nature so it was interesting to me learning about this kind of thing and i don't think you really need to know anything about them to enjoy this book after a while it seemed completely normal to be reading about the bees' lives i really enjoyed the themes explored in this novel despite the characters being bees the main themes of the novel were entirely relateable such as motherhood religion the environment a sense of home instinct vs control etc i think there were interesting ideas explored in a way that was highly effective making the reader feel closed in at points by the oppression of the society and the claustrophobia flora 717 is feeling overall i would highly recommend this book if you're looking for something completely different there were slow moments but on the whole this is a fast paced read and a great piece of fiction that would appeal to a wide range of readers

raw_text.2223: i won this book in a goodreads giveaway i will never look at bees the same way again i grew up in a wooded suburb area as such i was constantly surrounded by nature we had roses along with a myriad of other flowers that grew around our house these attracted bees i never though much of them they were neat little insects but after finishing this novel i feel like i have gotten a look inside of the day to day activity and turmoil of the life inside of a hive i really had no idea what to think when i began this novel a book written form the perspective of a bee sounds a little weird however i found myself sucked in almost immediately it's the kind of book where you tell yourself just one more chapter only to convince yourself the next chapter is short enough to read as well i assure you that cycle kept going this book follows flora 717 and her life inside the hive we meet the enemies of the bees learn of the strict queen centric religion if you will that all bees take part in and learn of all the struggles involved with life you see it's not just the job of a bee to go out and get pollen there are bees that clean and are morticians guard cook breed raise newborns and even the fertility police the latter of which reminds me of the nazi ss in their brutality it's all in the name of the betterment of the hive so what they do must be justified right if you are hesitant or trepidatious about buying this book don't be buy it read it love it the author really did a great job and i'm looking forward to seeing what she has up her sleeve next as a closing side note as i sat outside in the sun devouring the last few pages of this novel the first bee that i have seen this season lumbered over to me buzzed around a bit and departed in search of nectar could that bee have known what i was reading

raw_text.2235: the bees by laline paull is one of the most original books i have read in a long time the book tells the story of flora 717 a sanitation worker bee who is different from the other bees of her kind she is given special opportunities such as working in the nursery and flying out of the hive to forage for nectar and pollen but we can see that the bees' society is extremely restrictive with strict rules and limitations one who dares break a rule or question the power and authority of the queen and her inner circle risks the kindness or death we are shown the fascinating and horrifying culture of the bees whose religion is worship of their queen the christian prayer our father who art in heaven is adapted to our queen who art in labor there were aspects of this book that i really loved the story was clever and i loved the idea of a bee from a lower class challenging the upper class bees and that flora was something of a feminist bee who knows her own mind refusing to do whatever the drones demanded of her i also felt that i learned a lot about bees on the other hand there were parts of the book that i found very confusing although i am nothing of an expert on bees i think i probably know more than the average person as my father has been a beekeeper for more than 20 years but there were many behaviors by the bees in the book that i was unsure whether they were the creation of the author or some kind of anthropomorphism of bee behavior for example i don't know if bees actually have these rival groups within the hive which vie for control i became interested in this book when i saw it recommended on goodreads i am interested in bee society in all i recommend this book especially but not exclusively to readers interested in bees i also recommend it to people who like to see an underdog character struggle for freedom and opportunities

rewarded with death and while the author sets the story in a beehive among naturally bees she's really talking about us people of course flora 717 and the other bees in her hive think of themselves as raw_text.2255: i used to do my lunchtime reading in the office pantry and would occasionally get asked what's the book about now this question frustrates me on two levels first don't engage in a conversation with someone who's reading second i find it painfully difficult to answer that question from people who are only asking to make conversation don't ask me that if you are not genuinely interested because how can i condense the plot of a book in 140 characters or less which is how i am expected to answer that question it seems this tiny rant has a point my point is that this book will suffer so much when condensed to that sort of elevator talk it's a literary thriller about bees it sounds slightly absurd and shallow doesn't it when in fact the bees covers multiple layers of themes rich in parallels with the human experience this is one of the most highly original and compelling books i have ever read in fact i like that it is likened to margaret atwood's the handmaid's tale because it captures the same sort of chilling reality flora 717 is a sanitation bee the lowest level in the hive class she was born different in a society where different means dysfunction and leads to immediate death but flora was saved from immediate death to experiment how the hive can benefit from her abnormality from feeding the newborns to doing sanitation work with her kin to becoming a forager we journey with flora as she slowly discovers the different facets of the hive life fiercely loyal to the queen accept obey serve until flora breaks the sacred law of the hive the hive symbolizes power politics ruled by the queen it is a totalitarian government chosen because of her ability to breed but when flora spends time with queen mother we see someone who rules more on a ceremonial level she was almost a prisoner and a victim the real power belongs to the hive mind which controls and relays all the messages the hive symbolizes religion the queen mother as a ruler is treated as divine and her role to breed a divine right it is through devotions that the sage class who really are running the show behind the scenes can control and sway the sister bees the hive symbolizes the class struggle flora's kin being the sanitation workers the lowest class they are without the ability of speech and exist only to clean the foragers have probably the most physically demanding and dangerous task they leave the safety of the hive to collect pollen from all the flowers in the orchard they face many potential dangers in the form of wasps crows and spiders and the elements - rain wind and snow more than the class within the hive i think there is a bigger discussion in terms of nature's class power struggle man hardly figures in the story but when he does "visit" the hive it forces you to think about man's being at the top of food chain nature of self entitlement and disrespect for other creatures another aspect of flora's struggle that resonated with me was how lonely she is because she keeps a terrible secret flora constantly has to keep her antennae closed off to keep her secret safe when she develops a friendship with sir linden it was both heartbreaking and beautiful to see one last thing that i want to bring up is the respect i have gained for the honeybees we should realize how much hard work there is to produce honey and how they struggle with violence and danger everyday of their lives no spoilers here but there's one section that tackles how the bees handle the droughts of winter and it was the most chilling section of the book i was also awed at the complexity of the bees as an organism the sections about flora going to the garden to forage shows their physical strength in an interview with laline paull she mentions how signals are transmitted via the honeycombs through the bees' feet and legs which have sensors like our ears that can hear these signals very interesting creatures

raw_text.2271: one of the most amazing things that a book can do for you as a reader is to change the way you look at the world while reading this fictional account of life inside a bee hive i found myself contemplating the insect world around in me in a different light the bees tells the story of flora born into a sanitation caste within the hive flora is a special and talented bee in spite of her ugly appearance and rises to other roles including as a wet nurse within the nursery and as a forager in the orchards paull's research is comprehensive and very detailed readers will understand the workings of a hive in a way they never considered and the obvious comparisons to our own lives is absolutely fascinating the author has a beautiful command of language and she really makes the bee hive come alive flora becomes not just a cinderalla caricature in her rags to riches story but a full and complicated individual to whom i became very attached my only complaint with the bees is that the pace was uneven 10 pages of description of the wax in the hive would give way to a one page battle scene full of action as much as i loved living the life of a bee for the past week as i read this book i'd have preferred the editing be a little tighter

raw_text.2275: when i first read the nyt review of the bees by laline paull i immediately added it to my 'want to read' list but when i first started the book i wasn't quite so sure for the first few chapters i felt like i was in a margaret atwood novel what with all the sisterly bee rituals and arcane terminology but stay with it eventually you'll get past it and even stop wondering if all this bee stuff was based on the author's vast knowledge of bees or on her fantastical imagination i'm still not sure which it is but the book is really pretty good and flora 717 is a worthy heroine like all the bees she understands what her fellow bees are thinking through scent and vibration and touch however flora 717 is prone to speech and action and through these attributes as well as her ugliness and size she is singled out for very special duty 'accept obey and serve' is the bee mantra but flora 717 finds ways around those commands while still serving the hive i know that bees are currently endangered by colony collapse and that we should all become more aware of them but up until i read the bees my only real reaction to bees was to run when i saw one i'll still run but with a whole new regard for these remarkable insects and for laline paull

raw_text.2304: i found this rather an unusual read the novel takes you into the dystopia of a bee hive where society is a rigid social hierarchy centred on worship of the queen and enforced by a harsh regime flora 717 is born to the lowest class of bees but she is not a typical flora and quickly begins to rebel against her role in the hive paull's style is quite distinctive she conjures the sensory experience of the bees quite vividly in whirls of scent and chemical signals but sometimes this becomes rather repetitive and alienating similarly the routine plot of the underdog attempting to upset the system that holds them down has been done to death the saving grace of this novel is its unique setting and unusual look into a hidden world i found it to be increasingly absorbing and was fully invested in flora's adventures by the end
raw_text.2305: half way through the audio book and i love it i give the author credit for her ability to write from a unique perspective i can't help but wonder if there will be something in this work that reflects even a small appreciation for the drones or does the author simply hate men review after finishing this is a compelling story that will remind you of your impact on the environment while you learn about the inner workings of the beehive through the experiences of one tiny bee flora 717 who begins the underdog and rises to become a hero the only thing i didn't care for was the anti man undertone it was slightly resolved at the end but seemed too little to late this book leaves me wanting to learn more about the inner workings of the hive if the author stayed true to how bees actually behave one could learn a great deal while being entertained by a story that lends a humanistic view to the society of bees several in my family are beekeepers they'll all be getting this book as a gift from me i hope they enjoy it as much as i did

raw_text.2316: this is a very different piece of fiction whoever thought that an interesting book could be written about a bee hive but here it is flora 717 is a sanitation worker but seems to possess unique qualities that get her noticed by the powers that be it takes awhile to get used to the tight little community and all the rules 'accept obey and serve' is the mantra of every bee in the hive lots of fascinating facts swarming over the winter to save on energy the tireless foraging for pollen and nectar interesting battles with spiders and flies enemies of bees and of course the dreaded wasps once you get used to the sense of overwhelming control and routine you can applaud flora as she changes throughout the story despite the rigid controls of the hive in the end i really liked flora and gained a new appreciation for bees struggling against environmental factors that threaten their very existence
raw_text.2317: flora 717 is a rebel plain and simple shes gone where no other bee has gone before shes acted on her instincts and gone against the herd swarm i suppose it would be for bees a sanitation bee in her hive shes the lowest of all the ranks available the bottom of the pile and last hope this doesn't stop flora she knows what she wants and knows that she isn't meant to conform with the crowd shes different and now is time to show it the idea for this book struck me as original and was in essence the main reason why i gave this a read aside from the striking almost luminous yellow cover this is book is a feat of written engineering very short chapters throwing you right into the main story arc showing us really what flora is made of i'd rather not put anything here that could spoil the early going for new readers but this is actually a very good book intensely gripping and highly emotional in parts who'd have that i'd be writing that a book about bees is emotional but it just is the only thing that really struck me as odd is strange and sometimes disjointed anthropomorphising take a breath of the bees themselves their 'claws' are clearly their version of human hands but in some parts they're using normal human type objects plates etc which just didn't sit right with me for some reason or another however as i've said in other reviews this is really only a minor thing and doesn't take anything away if this doesn't look like your typical read then give it a go anyway challenge your ideas and just give it a try that's what i did and i loved it dystopian fiction at is peak

raw_text.2323: the bees by laline paull was a surprise the subject matter did not appeal to me the premise did not appeal to me but everything i read suggested that i would enjoy the book i absolutely did enjoy the book it grabbed me almost immediately with the main character of flora 717 i do not know a lot about bees and how a hive works the hierarchy of the bees was also a surprise i have to admit - really i only knew i liked them for my flowers as they spread the pollen around laline paull taught me so much about bees without preaching or orating a lot of information i found myself wanting to know more and the whys and wherefores the bees follows the life of one bee that did not fit or stay in her assigned class her movement allowed us to witness other working parts of a hive the caste system of the beehive and the mistreatment of so by the "upper classes" could parallel so many situations in our hive of earth another parallel the book makes includes the use of pesticides and their effect on the population of the hive i found this portion of the story a powerful statement about how poisoning our world while seeming to control it has unexpected results the book was really quite a surprise to me i did enjoy it i did find it very interesting i did find the story relevant to people and to this time a really solid read

raw_text.2325: i found this book very reminiscent of watership down except with bees obviously there were some really interesting moments but there were also some rather slow parts that i found myself skimming through i never seemed able to grasp whether the bees were meant to have real emotions beneath their basic insect mentality as they had moments where one would consider them almost human in thought but then many more moments where they simply acted as a bee would this made it hard to become invested in our main character or care about where her life was going i also think that some moments that were meant to be shocking simply weren't if you were viewing the characters as actual bees as opposed to intelligent emotional creatures things came together in the end and gave the story more of the purpose that i was wanting i just wish it had come a bit sooner
raw_text.2326: the bees is beautifully written laline paull has a knack for eloquently describing the scenes in her fantasy bee world from the first page i was sucked into the hive and felt like i was a part of the colony it is obvious that paull did an incredible amount of research on bees in order to write this book the bees is a story that personifies bees and their plight for survival the heroine flora is born a sanitation worker the lowest class of bee in the colony but there is something different about flora she can talk and she feels an insatiable pull towards motherhood unfortunately the only bee in the colony who can beget offspring is the queen and the punishment for any bee who lays an egg is death the bees is paull's debut novel and has been shortlisted for the 2015 baileys women's prize for fiction i absolutely loved the lucid quality of paull's writing she describes her scenes brilliantly captivating and immersing the reader into flora's world a golden mist and a soft harmonic chord shimmered from the centre of the atrium the six towering walls were made of interlocking chalices of honey capped and consecrated with the queen's seal and curved in to make a domed ceiling far below stood hundreds of sisters in concentric circles all fanning their silver wings their faces were joyous and blank and before each was a large chalice of raw nectar from these vessels the mist and music spiralled into the air as the water evaporated from the nectar thickening it to honey laline paull the beesalthough the bees is sweetly written there is a vicious venom throughout the book before the young bee could speak the two officers pressed her head down until there was a sharp crack she hung limp between them and they dropped her body in the corridor laline paull the beesjust as in nature flora experiences the beautiful awesomeness of life but is also faced with the dark necessity of violence and death because flora is pulled towards motherhood her life within the hive is precarious and could be violently ended at any moment she is in a constant state of fear but she manages to remain strong and appreciate her gift of life while following flora's life in the hive the reader is faced with three issues that hint at paull's view of humanity one is an insane cult like religion of which the queen bee is god i'm not sure if paull is attempting to praise or persecute organized religion i did however find the religious reference added an interesting dynamic to the hive and lent a justification for the violence within the colony another human issue is the class system within the hive and the hatred for other races outside the hive paull also describes the destruction that industrialized farming and pesticide use create she infers that this type of farming is anything but beautiful below her spread the great plain of different greens pushed together in crude four sided shapes as if by some primitive insect ignorant of the beauty of the hexagon laline paull the beesi thought the metaphors were a little weak i was also a little confused by the human scened prologue and epilogues the meaning of these escaping me within the book paull depicts spiders as fortune tellers and mind readers again i'm unsure as to what is meant by this why do the spiders understand life within the hive so well and why are they able to read flora's mind however the underlying theme of the book is the strength of a mother's love and this wisdom rang loud clear and true throughout the bees as a gardener i have a special place in my heart for bees and the bees by laline paull has intensified my love for these helpful critters although the metaphors in the book are lacking and somewhat confusing i still adored the story which had just the right amount of sweetness and venom i will never look at bees the same since reading the bees checkout the review on my website to learn what tea pairs best with this book come read with me on instagram

raw_text.2328: this is just weird it isn't my first foray into alternative ideas or weird fiction i've got a few in my corner from bizarro fiction after all but this just seemed like the author tried something that didn't quite pan out it comes down to this the bees were anthropomorphic enough to talk and dance and have a religion but were too bee ish to make me actually care about what happened to them maybe that sounds callous because i should care about bees but i don't at least not in the way i care about human people and that ultimately is the problem flora 717 is human like enough to feel love and shame and reverence but then there's constant references to her engine starting those are the literal words used and then i'm just rudely reminded how foreign they are to me plus something i had a really hard time with was the way the male bees were treated the way the females fawned all over them made me gag a little again if i'm meant to treat these bees as if they're something i can relate to the author did not bridge the gap they treat the males like living and breathing gods draping themselves on him and cleaning them and being at their every beck and call it was weird like sneaking a look into a perverted guy's brain a douchebag type who imagines hordes of gorgeous young women licking his feet and fanning him with palm tree fronds and hand feeding him grapes it definitely didn't work for me it just wasn't enough i appreciate what the author went for and i appreciate going for an entirely new idea but the actual application left much to be desired

raw_text.2341: i received a copy of this book for free from the publisher in exchange for an honest review also posted on my blog rinn reads i wasn't sure what to expect when i first received a copy of the bees a story told from the point of view of a bee it sounded like it could be really wonderful and unique or really fall flat luckily this was definitely the former the bees follows flora a sanitation worker bee from the lowest kin within the hive the hive is separated into kins each named after plants and flowers such as sage lily thistle etc and each with 'typical' duties for example the sages being priestess type figures floras are normally mute and unable to fly but flora defies all expectations of her kin and proves herself capable of any job that the hive can throw at her the story follows flora as she tries to work out her purpose in this very strict society whilst it might sound like a very strange concept laline paull has taken a really wonderful step in creating this story i think we need more books told from the point of view of unusual and unexpected protagonists i found myself entranced by her writing not only her style but also the way in which she told flora's story it might seem odd to read about bees doing things we expect from humans such as dancing but in this case paull makes it fit in the bees 'dance' in order to communicate with fellow gatherers the paths that they should take to collect nectar and remain safe even though this is not dancing as we know it i completely understood what paull meant it was so so vivid i could easily imagine the hive and everything within it the structure of the hive was quite terrifying almost a dystopian 'big brother' society where everyone has to stick to their assigned duties and anyone who breaks rules or has no purpose is killed what i loved most about the book was how alive everything felt plants flowers bees and other insects - paull's writing brought so much life to all of them if you're a little unsure of this title because of the strange topic i would definitely say don't hesitate and give it a try it'll certainly make you think about how important bees are within our ecosystem and what really goes on in the hive
raw_text.2342: i can be quite honest that i was not very engrossed during the first half i found flora's constant job changing unrealistic although necessary to the plot and it suspended my belief in the story i also was unsatisfied that it was never revealed as to what made her a superior size intelligence diversity bee than the rest of the sanitation workers the second half showed an improvement maybe that was because i was curious to see if i had guessed 'it' right maybe it was because more things were happening although somethings were just so repetitive great if you're a bee not so great if your iq is a bit higher and you long for variation but having said that there are some things i want to respect about this book firstly i have never read anything like this a story about a bee and her hive secondly i appreciated the lack of sentimentality over death mostly in nature it is always around the corner lastly i have to appreciate how a close look at something non human can allow us to make judgements on our own society the prayer for the mother which is a clear allusion to the lord's prayer allows an opportunity to question religion were the sages really doing the queens work or were they there for their own benefit the hierarchy of the bees in the hive are also very similar to those found in ours it is because of this that i think there is definite value to this book it allows for multiple opportunities to examine our own world perhaps one that could do with some thought is that everything the bees did was for the good of the hive an area in which their society is superior to ours

raw_text.2355: last night i finished reading the bees by laline paull harpercollins 2014 i am still in mourning i know all readers will understand what i mean--that sensation when you can't stop reading a book but with every fibre of your being you wish it would never end the bees was an enveloping read that followed the journey of flora 717 a worker bee with a defect--and boy was it a journey born a sanitation worker the lowest class in the bee hive flora is thrust up through the ranks rubbing shoulders with the queen and filling the coveted position of a forager she soon manages to break every rule in the hive including one incredibly important one but i won't ruin the ending for you flora's journey is filled with drama and conflict but what i loved most about the bees was paull's amazing description of life in a hive while i could relate to the human aspects of flora's character i loved how she identified other types of bees by their scent her deep connection to her hive and her "sister" bees and even her relationship with flowers with its dystopian style writing and messages about the efficacy of class systems the bees is definitely a worthwhile read for lovers of the hunger games and the handmaid's tale rating 4 5 5

raw_text.2361: accept obey serve only the queen may breed these are the mottoes of the hive in laline paul's the bees a world in which flora 717 a sanitation worker and the lowest class in the hierarchy of her hive is required to follow wholeheartedly or she faces certain death as we witness flora's birth in the first few pages we immediately know that she is special different from the hundreds of other low level bees in her hive flora discovers early on that she can speak that she produces flow an important nourishing substance to feed larvae and that she possesses another exceptional secret ability that sets her apart from all of her sisters all the bees in a hive are female throughout the book flora overcomes great challenges rain foraging wasps crows to conceal her gift from the those that threaten her existence all in all i liked this book and i don't even like bees i run in fear whenever one flies close to me but i found myself fascinated by the many things i learned about these fascinating creatures i never knew bees' lives were so complex this novel was a drastic departure from what i normally read because i typically don't go for stories that feature animal characters paul's writing however worked beautifully here bees became less scary and human for me i felt genuine happiness when flora and her kin survived to fight another day and dare i say it sadness when one of the little buggers around her died i read this book thinking wow i am officially a bee sympathizer now comparisons to the handmaid's tale will be inevitable here whether the author intended to or not there are all of the earmarks of a dystopian fiction novel the constant repetition of the accept obey serve motto is at the center of the hive mind there's thought reading social control as well as questions and considerations surrounding reproductive freedom to ponder all in all this is a thoroughly enjoyable read that i highly recommend

raw_text.2375: flora 717 is a sanitation worker a member of the lowest caste in her orchard hive where work and sacrifice are the highest virtues and worship of the beloved queen the only religion but flora is not like other bees with circumstances threatening the hive's survival her curiosity is regarded as a dangerous flaw but her courage and strength are assets she is allowed to feed the newborns in the royal nursery and then to become a forager flying alone and free to collect pollen she also finds her way into the queen's inner sanctum where she discovers mysteries about the hive that are both profound and ominous but when flora breaks the most sacred law of all--daring to challenge the queen's fertility--enemies abound from the fearsome fertility police who enforce the strict social hierarchy to the high priestesses jealously wedded to power her deepest instincts to serve and sacrifice are now overshadowed by an even deeper desire a fierce maternal love that will bring her into conflict with her conscience her heart her society--and lead her to unthinkable deeds the goodreads description of this book says "the handmaid's tale meets the hunger games " i've never read the hunger games so i can't comment on that comparison and it's been decades since i've read the handmaid's tale however i did come to the same conclusion on my own before reading the gr blurb --there were definitely echoes of the handmaid's tale in the bees the supervision of reproduction aspect especially i was also reminded strongly of orwell's 1984 huxley's brave new world and zamyatin's we the "serve accept obey" slogan for example or the fertility police several other reviewers whose opinions i respect have also pointed out some parallels with watership down mostly because of the anthropomorphic nature of thinking talking animals i speculate the bees was an enjoyable read and a quick one--if i had an earlier start i would have finished it in one evening i had two chapters left when i realized that i would be miserable at work the next day if i didn't bundle myself off to bed immediately although i had foreseen the end of the novel by about 2 3 of the way through it was still fun to see how it was realized i find the scenes where bees used brooms and or dustpans a little bit twee and would have preferred that those human artifacts hadn't been mentioned--i found they jarred me out of the narrative a bit especially when the natural behaviour of the insects was generally so well represented one thing that makes the bees unlike the books above is the commentary on environmental issues--the dearth of flowers to supply food for the hive and the repercussions of pesticide use on crops since i personally am a recovering arachnophobic i really identified with the horror of the spider scenes i know that spiders are necessary in the circle of life and i leave them alone unless they come into my home but they still bother me one part that i was especially fond of was the tying together of the first and last chapters using the family of the home in whose yard the bee hive sits perhaps because i'm the age where under normal circumstances i would be dealing with living arrangements for elderly parents i found this very touching my parents died young and in many ways i would love to have this problem to cope with--instead my sisters and i dealt with possessions and sold the family farm house almost 20 years ago i'm not sure what kind of staying power the bees will have over the long term how many books are instant classics i'm unsure of that and it will likely be up to future readers to grant or deny "classic" status on any of today's books past classics weren't up against the flood of titles available in the 21st century and i often wonder if or how many of the current year's offering will end up durable and memorable enough to achieve that kind of status but i think it does at least have a chance and i'm very glad that i read it
raw_text.2376: one young female flora dares to challenge the order of the society in which she lives a totalitarian caste ridden decaying matriarchal society in in which the apparent ruler is little more than a puppet figurehead for a coterie of ruling elite priestesses the society is kept in order by the 'state police' and kept subdued by the euphemistic 'queens love at first flora's challenge is unwitting but as her stature grows in her society she learns of its secrets hidden from the lower casts her challenge morphs from unwitting to a deliberate rebellion to authority though her instinct still keeps best interests of her society at heart tales like this have been penned before and will be again and they have happened but this is not a tale of human society though it could be laline paull's heroine is flora 717 a sanitation worker bee born into the lowest caste in her hive from birth she as are all the bees is indoctrinated to accept obey serve her hive paull's story takes us deep inside the bee hive and deep into the hive mind when the hive has a visitation from its bee keeper you almost seem to be peering through the drifting smoke as he removes combs of honey the bees is both a thought provoking story and it is also a compelling allegory of aspects of human behaviour when a ruling elite tries to protect its own position at the expense of the common good as i worked my way through the book i found myself caring about some of the insect characters more than some human characters in other stories i found the bees an enthralling read that held my attention page after page laline paull's story will appeal to people who liked tales such as watership down and the duncton chronicals it should appeal to anyone who enjoys a good thriller and thought provoking tale

raw_text.2379: this was a fascinating story about the life of a worker bee flora 717 who is born in a honey community as a sanitation worker flora though has skills beyond the normal sanitation worker and she is able to do other duties such as work in the nursery and even forage for pollen the author does give the bees human qualities that are fantastical for bees such as greed hate etc but some qualities makes one wonder animals do feel sorrow joy and pain they mourn their losses and celebrate their joy do bees well whether or not you think so certainly bees have their own lives and a whole world outside our own human world many things that the author describes in human terms are things that the bees actually do such as dance for the other bees to describe desirable locations of flowers or of new nesting sites very enjoyable read

raw_text.2397: i was pleasantly surprised by this book initially i had only bought it out of curiosity as to how a novel could be written about bees all the while being somewhat convinced that bees would turn out to be a code name for spies or maybe revolutionaries in some dystopian future after realising that the book was actually about the life of bees in a hive i did initially find it difficult to get in to however once you get past that initial uncertainty you begin to experience more of paull's portrayal of the bees with many human like characteristics while still maintaining their insect qualities you find yourself relating to them whilst being acutely aware that they are bees throughout you can see themes of feminism the way in which the male drones are revered just for being male religion the queen bee is treated like a goddess and the house bees are expected to worship her and abide by her wishes and predominantly it really makes you think about the environment and the effect we have on the world simple things like the forager bees going out and being unable to gather from the flowers by the road because they are tainted overall the novel has a fantastic entertaining storyline that really draws you in as well as being interesting and thought provoking
raw_text.2398: strikingly different original bizarre awe inspiring mystical these are phrases used to describe laline paull's the bees and it's true reading this novel is like drifting into an acid trip that introduces you to unimaginable brand new colors important note speaking figuratively here i've never actually tried acid but the bees is undeniably trippy everything in it is both familiar and foreign a dreamy hushed otherworld that operates according to fascinating immutable and utterly un human laws the story centers around flora 717 a sanitation worker born into the lowest caste in her hive obedience industry and sacrifice define the lives of the colony along with worship of the queen without question the bees accept the instructions of the hive mind which are communicated by scent pheromones and vibrations and they toil selflessly at their preordained tasks some are nursery carers some are patisserie workers some are foragers who fly into the vastness outside the hive to collect pollen the female bees have the kin names of flowers flora 717 sister sage lily 500 the males who are ahem giant buffoonish sex fiends loll around like wasted frat boys stealing everyone's food and burping out lewd catcalls there are very few males in the hive though and they are indulged and honored without intending to flora 717 goes rogue right from the moment of her birth escaping from the reviled drudgery of sanitation as she discovers that she is different from all the other bees diversity needless to say is not a hive virtue flora 717's odyssey through all the areas of the hive--feeding babies in the nursery braving the terrors of the outside world as a forager flighting off enemy wasps and spiders--culminates with an act of unthinkable sedition when she must challenge every sacred instinct of the hive for the even more elementary pull of maternal love the bees avoids completely anthropomorphizing its characters--they don't come across to me as small fuzzy humans--but instead are alien otherworldly creatures who operate under unfathomable rules there are all kinds of potential human comparisons--religious allegories animal farm type political messages the nature of free will--but to me the salient thing about the book was its inventive weirdness the writing is lovely and the author's imagination is staggering i wanted to keep reading it because it was so different

what i usually read while waiting for other books i have on hold to come through the bees is what the title says it is a book about a colony of bees but it is also so much more than that it is indeed raw_text.2409: a sanitation worker a member of the lowest and most disregarded caste it's obvious from the moment she emerges from her cell that flora 717 is different to her kin she's bigger more alert more articulate and more able to question her environment she's going to be trouble both to herself and to the community of bees into which she has been bornneedless to say flora 717's unique qualities are not looked upon favourably by the hive's ruling caste and it's only a matter of time before she finds herself alienated from the hive mind as she struggles to hide her rebellious thoughts and treacherous behaviour the bees has been described as watership down for the hunger games generation it has also been compared to the handmaid's tale and there is definitely an interesting commentary on gender roles and society being sketched out here what is most interesting about this novel for me however is the alien nature of the environment and of the characters who populate it this is a world in which the most important sense is smell it's a world in which individual thought is over ruled by the imperatives of the hive mind and the good of the community is far more important than the survival of the individual laline paull succeeds remarkably well in bringing that world to life and making it convincing the result is an unusual and very enjoyable read

raw_text.2424: the concept is buzz worthy okay that's my one and only lame ass pun i swear 'the bees' by laline paull really does have an outstanding concept the idea of setting a dystopian book in a bee hive with all we know of it's structure and hierarchy is very interesting due to that fact it's a bit of a shame that the writing and plot structure fall quite flat this book instantly begins with our characters birth she is 'flora 717' and born into the sanitation level of the hierarchy the lowest of the low shit shoveler if you will we follow our character as she ages goes about her work until all of a sudden she pops out an egg knowing as a 'worker bee' she's not allowed too dystopian metaphors obviously ensue well sort of you see 'the bees' doesn't really seem to care all too much about it's own dystopia it's instead interested in telling you how and what every bee does within it's colony now don't get me wrong i found the educational aspect of this book quite enjoyable it's obvious that the author did a great amount of research but you can sort of tell that she learned a lot and wanted to include as much as possible instead of it feeling organic to the story we have our little lowly sanitation bee getting promotion after promotion up the hierarchy just so we can be told all about different zones and jobs its quite mary sue like and it just didn't gel well with me personally the characters themselves are obviously humanised but given very little character overall meaning we care about no one and also certain bees only stand out simply because of their 'class' in the system there's an interesting note about sacrificing the lower bees to spiders for pearls of wisdom but overall it's lacking my rating of two stars reflects all that i've stated above it just doesn't feel like a cohesive novel for me and instead feels like a fictional story someone has tried to create to provide educational value it just wasn't engrossing 2 stars

raw_text.2428: a lovely though at times terrifying novel that touches on totalitarianism and religion as well as being a reminder of how valuable bees are sort of a watership down with insects if you want to be glib like that novel the author has done her research and as far as i can tell most of the descriptions of behaviour etc are accurate including some of the more distressing ones although there are some conceits like the queen and her ladies dressing in mantles of waxy lace and styling their fur and wasps painting around their eyes to look more fearsome linden is a brilliant secondary character but flora 717 steals the show as she should being the heroine although it's never quite explained why she is so different apart from some hints that she's a hybrid with another type of bee she discovers her maternal instinct over the course of the story and this is another of its themes the strength of maternal bonds and not just between the queen and her offspring the best element for me was the way the author described scent and how it impacted on the bees and informed and controlled their every moment scent is an important sense to me and i think she described it perfectly rather than trying to explain what a scent was like she just says it was the scent of love of devotion of punishment etc and it's easy for the imagination to fill in the blanks i so enjoyed this and as i said it's a valuable reminder of why bees are precious and why they might not be too keen on us taking their honey

raw_text.2435: i enjoyed this book and would give it three and half stars i think it deserves five stars for the wonderfully imaginative way it depicts bees and how the author incorporated her research in a engaging interesting way and four stars for the writing which was for the most part excellent where it failed for me was in the plot and character development the plot was often repetitive and sometimes seemed like a checklist of every bee event birth and care of larvae check attack by predators check gathering nectar check survival or not in winter check etc the two most complete characters were flora 717 the narrator and sir linden a drone the other characters were nebulous more representations priestesses cleaners foragers than actual personalities i think the priestess who the author introduces in the first pages should have been developed and used throughout the book she disappears half way or so into the novel there also seemed to be a conflict in style it was sometimes quite an accurate depiction of bees speaking about the molecules of chemicals entering their spiracles for example and then suddenly the workers are using dustpans and brushes and making pollen cakes in a patisserie i also found the inclusion of doors staircases secret rooms and unused passages hard to imagine in such a limited space the reader is then thrust into a shakespearean comedy with lewd and lusty lordling drones making merry i loved the drone sections but i found the sudden changes in style disruptive and confusing the incidences of conflict that flora 717 suffered between her secret desires and the good of the hive also became too numerous and tedious i want to do but my hive needs me so i must forage clean etc decide already i was also a little disturbed by the depiction of wasps flies and spiders as evil dirty creatures though i suppose this was from the bees' viewpoint there were other threads that were not developed at all why were the spiders such omniscient creatures who knew the deepest secrets of the hive why was flora 717 the way she was there is the casual mention of a foreign drone from the south but that's it and what about the thousands of other eggs he fathered there were many aspects of the novel i loved the kins of the hive named for various flowers and the sensual relationship between bee and flower and i look forward to the author's next novel

raw_text.2467: except obey and serve accept obey and serve this is the mantra of the hive the law for life within following this simple rule everything is done for the benefit of the hive its sisters and most importantly its queen each echelon of the hive hierarchy strives to do her part to be industrious and to promote harmony flora 717 belongs to the lowest and most humble kin of her hive and would normally spend her days as a sanitation worker cleaning up after the other bees however flora is anything but ordinary she seems to change the hive motto to except obey and serve through a series of events she discovers her aptitude for various other hive jobs from nursery worker to forager and as she grows in knowledge she realizes startling truths about her life and about the future of the hive her discoveries lead her to break the cardinal rule and the most pressing question is what she should do and whether her actions are feats of loyalty or of treachery to herself and to the queen laline paull creates a fabulously imaginative and provocative debut novel that resonates with both beauty and horror readers see the world and experience life within the hive through the eyes of a worker bee who proves to be extraordinary her exceptional rendering of what life as a bee entails causes one to view honeybees in a different light borrowing some concepts from catholicism she likens the hive experience to a honeybee religion that honors the queen mother the bees is a thrilling journey through the cycles of a beehive and through flora 717 readers experience how one bee's remarkable life influences and affects those around her despite the recognition of individual bees only as members of their kin so that each kin member has the same name paull manages to develop several memorable leading characters also while sex is a topic that is discussed in the novel it is done so for the most part in a thoughtful and non explicit manner this story captures the imagination and will have readers holding their breath until the final page

raw_text.2475: the bees by laline paull has to be one of the strangest books i've ever read not because it's bad but because of its uniqueness i happen to work at a bookstore and when i first saw this book i was intrigued by the design and the expensive soft leathery feel of its cover upon reading the description my intrigue only grew further a book...about bees for adults as i opened the book i was astonished to find a whopping 19 reviews inside surely if so many esteemed authors praised this book there must be something to it right but still... a book... about bees... for adults weird i am happy to report however that this book is phenomenal in chapter one we meet flora 717 she's unusual to say the least having been born just a little too big and a little too ugly she is almost killed immediately by the fertility police yes you read that correctly the fertility police kill all that are deformed mutated or show any sign of illness for such things are evil and sinful and must be destroyed flora it turns out is not your typical bee though born to the lowest class of bees and originally destined to a life as a lowly sanitation worker scrubbing floors and attending the morgue we find that she possesses unique abilities that allow her to serve the hive in various ways accept obey serve these are the words that flora and her sisters live by to them it's not just a mantra it's something born in them to think an independent thought or to challenge the set rules of law invites death the bees touches on such issues as class struggle religious oppression police brutality political maneuvering and of course love the fact that you're seeing these through the eyes of a bee doesn't take away from the gravity of these issues i found it very rewarding to watch flora go from a newborn to a prominent member of society all while battling her internal and external demons as she discovered herself and the truth of her world as you immerse yourself into flora's world it becomes difficult to remember that she and all her sisters are bees the internal imaginings of this fantastic world and the real one are very hard to reconcile so i just stopped trying trying to imagine a bee doing a curtsy for example is much harder and also funnier than you'd expect i found it easier to imagine this anthropomorphically rather than literally this isn't to say that the book is perfect for no book is a case could be made that ms paull embellished a few things too many regarding how the hive works there are also some parts of the book that feel a little rushed twice i had to go back and read something again to see where it transitioned from point a to point b these are minor complaints and with most fantastical works you have to embrace a certain suspension of disbelief fortunately ms paull proves to be capable of writing a story that makes this quite easy the more i read the more a felt i had a connection and understanding of bees it goes without saying that certain aspects of the bee world had to be embellished hello they're bees who can talk and have religion but you really feel like you're getting a lesson in apiology i even put on a documentary about bees while i was reading because i found myself so engrossed in this world i also appreciated how much detail we receive regarding the hive itself the illustrious royal library and the nurseries are particular favorites i found myself imagining vast halls you'd expect to find in royal palaces and almost wishing i was a bee except not a male bee because as much as i'd like to be pampered i'd also not like to die from having sex or face being slaughtered for not having sex basically male bees get screwed literally and figuratively anyway moving on... i give this book 5 stars and am already looking for business partners to start a bee farm

raw_text.2477: read for bookgroup my summary of discussion was as expected it proved a discussion provoking piece covering aspects of religion caste systems female hierarchies ecological issues and whether spiders really do have all the answers we made the most of having a bee keeper's wife in the mix and learned a lot about the way a hive works the main difficulty we found with the book was the crossing of genres a mix of fantasy bees making pastries and cleaning up with dustpans and brushes and reference bees really do dance to show the way to good flowers unfortunately this left a space in the middle where it was difficult to tell the fact from fiction which left several of us with unanswered questions we gave the book a respectable average of 6 3 std dev ~1 5 for the numeracy loving among you and decided that we'd recommend it to anyone curious about bees with the understanding that you might have to take some of the content with a pinch of salt
raw_text.2478: the bees is a fast paced sci fi which is wholly original in its concept but it still shares many of the same classic dystopian themes that i love within this genre our protagonist is called flora 717 a common sanitation bee who has been born with an abnormal deformity for she is significantly larger and darker in colour than the other sanitation bees whose job it is to simply clean the hive and do nothing more in addition to her unusual physical appearance she also has the ability to speak which the priestess sister sage picks up on sage takes a risk by moving flora 717 up the hierarchy by giving her a position in the nursery and this is where things start to go awry flora 717 starts to think past the usual 'accept obey serve' commands and begins to understand how the hive works cue lots of political drama corruption scandal and a bizarre but dare i say 'realistic' insight into how a hive may operate under the fascist queen needless to say i drew many comparisons between the bees and watership down and there were even hints of the handmaid's tale in there too an interesting read to say the least

raw_text.2493: fantastic i wasn't sure i wanted to read this as i tend to shy away from anything written from the point of view of anything from the animal kingdom but once i got into this i could not put it down flora is an amazingly well created character and life in the hive is absolutely riveting and i found myself caring about flora and her kin more than i thought possible i now want to watch the documentary more than honey to learn about these fascinating creatures i will never look at honey in the same way the publisher describes this as a cross between hunger games and handmaid's tale but i don't think that's an entirely accurate description as this book defies any sort of label read it in may when it's released and see if you don't agree this is an excellent choice for book groups an added note from a readers' advisory pov one of our more challenging questions comes from patrons who want a novel that will take them out of their nonfiction rut something that helps them learn something new and this book works well for those kinds of requests we call them nonfiction novels it also incorporates all of the appeal factors that work for just about anyone looking for a good book stunning setting fabulous characters even if they are bees intriguing story and great writing so you know it's coming don't you it's a honey of a book

raw_text.2496: this novel is like charlotte's web meets game of thrones it is truly one of the most imaginative books that has been released in a very long time dystopian fiction has been on the rise over the past few years with sagas such as the hunger games and divergent having achieved huge success and catapulted their young stars into a whole new realm of fame equally pixar and dreamworks have brought us several films that imagined the lives of insects with a bug's life bee movie and antz the tone of these franchises are markedly different however and in drawing them together laline paull has created something very original flora 717 is from the very lowest social rung of the hive only fit to be a sanitation worker she lives in a world that revolves around devotion to the queen the mantra accept obey serve rules her days and the highest commandment is that only the queen may breed the fertility police roam the corridors the sage priestesses can read the thoughts of the workers and the bees recognise each other by scent flora is a feisty one and not prepared to accept the role that her society has set her her earnestness leading her far beyond the life mapped out for her for my full review http girlwithherheadinabook blogspo

raw_text.2506: you might like this book if 1 you enjoy watership down 2 you are curious about bees and their way of life3 you want to read something bizarre and different4 you are looking for a book with an original dystopian society not another hunger games divergent copycat the bees is a surprisingly 1 original 2 action packed and 3 emotional for the first half of the book i kept asking myself why do i keep reading this it's the weirdest most bizarre thing i've ever had my hands on and it doesn't even have a human logic to it seriously the whole book is written from the perspective of a worker bee trying to fit in a strict fanatic society survive the calamities that befall her hive and guard her ultimate secret view spoiler her ability to lay eggs hide spoiler i went into this book without knowing much about this particular insect and its way of life but by the 60% i had the strong unbearable urge to watch bee documentaries there are some pretty good ones actually of course apart from the fact that worker bees are supposed to die after they sting the author really knows her stuff ok but that's not even the point the world building is amazing the psychology and structure of a bee society is already interesting and weird enough but add a little bit of dystopia interaction with other species and real life ecological issues and i cannot complain the character development is superb the protagonist starts of as any other weak minded rule obeying worker and she gradually becomes a strong and independent leader to her people her journey is truly fascinating but i had a real problem with her being so brainwashed in the beginning the conclusion was epic there is a lot of action and fights in this book makes you feel sorry for the real bees yet the ending was also surprisingly emotional thank you laline paull for bringing us a remarkable highly original and emotional story
