raw_text.2524: many thanks to dung beetle for the recommendation on this novel i listened to the audiobook narrated by orlagh cassidy via the local library i'm not quite sure i agree with the blurb the handmaid's tale meets the hunger games i'd put watership down in the second slot with a touch of forrest gump and 1984thrown in for good measure flora 717 is our protagonist she is born into the lowest caste in her hive but there's something different about her that catches the eye of one of the priestesses with sister sage's help flora transcends her birth status by becoming a nursery worker an attendant to the queen and a forager however she unintentionally transgresses the highest law and triggers a serious disruption to the hive paull takes what is currently understood about of bee biology and behavior and builds a complex anthropomorphic yet alien society on it the drones are portrayed as lazy aristocracy and the queen as a goddess on earth with caste politics driving the story elements that seem alien at first glance scent paths shared memories are presented in context and quickly become part of the overall environment flora's adventures and experiences provide some genuine thrills and suspense with some of the most dramatic scenes involving drones and princesses being drawn from actual bee behavior paull creates a richly imagined environment in this novel and flora 717 is a fully rounded character accompanied by well drawn supporting characters like sir linden and sister sage i really enjoyed this novel and have added it to my tobuy list i can also recommend the audiobook u0026amp may be looking to see what else orlagh cassidy has narrated
raw_text.2525: i listened to this on audiobook and i'm glad i did i think i might have struggled in places if i had been reading the book although i was taken with the story of flora 717 certain aspects of the book ie the description of the bees' senses scents vibrations etc became a little repetitive and i think the novel would have benefited by being shorter even listening to the narration my mind sometimes wandered on the positive side almost as soon as i was introduced to flora i was enchanted by her character and as i read more about her became more concerned for her welfare and indeed the hive in general laline paull's descriptions of the hive are very vivid and easy to visualise in my mind's eye as were the different characteristics of the other bees wasps and the terrifying myriad i was shocked at how brutal the bees can be towards each other life is cheap in a hive looking at life through the eyes of a bee was interesting and when the little flora 717 was hatched an exciting adventure began i'm glad i completed flora's story when i reached the final pages i hadn't realised how attached i had become to her character and found the ending very emotional for an author to write a novel about a bee hive and make it as interesting and educational as it was is g genius i think laline paull did an excellent job i would like a hive in the garden now but i wouldn't steal their honey they work too hard for it

raw_text.2553: there is a strangely religious quality to the way in which the bees interact with one another showing holy devotion to their queen the mother and addressing one another as 'sister' in fact the book has been compared to margaret atwood's the handmaid's tale it is the females who work together for the sake of the hive and whilst being female signifies the ability to child bear only the chosen may breed those who are not will be destroyed by the state it can be difficult to follow the biological patterns of the bees who use hormones to communicate emotions and thrive on the 'devotion' that flows to them through the hive courtesy of the queen their mother if the reader focuses purely on the science of the species and i praise paull for her incredible display of knowledge it can be difficult to enjoy the novel for what it is a story this was my mistake to begin with however after a few chapters i sternly told myself to relax and enjoy the novel just because the biological references were new to me it didn't mean that i needed to focus on them in order to understand the plot they were certainly educational but i don't believe that this is the message paull intended to display flora 717 the protagonist shows true spirit of character as she works her way up the ranks from the lowest class within the hive learning about the different roles including nursing to offspring waiting on the queen and foraging for pollen the conflicts she encounters on her journey through life are compelling to read with paull writing with incredibly sensory detail that makes flora feel three dimensional read more at www thepaperadventure com

raw_text.2571: i got this in audiobook form i must say i am not a bee fan normally the story was wonderfully written and i really enjoyed hearing the bees stories seeing their lives inside the hive the narrative by orlagh cassidy was superb and so aided my enjoyment of the book flora 717 is the lead character flora is a lowly worker bee but has intelligence and insight into her world which sets her apart the hive is a very rigid place obedience and subservience are key the day to day world of the bee is explored including their 'scent' and 'codes' of the hive absorbed through the vibrations of the floor tiles the bees transmit 'information' through their antennae i loved their folklore including their animosity with wasps the drones are such characters they swagger and puff themselves out they are competitive and devoted to 'her majesty' the skill of the writing ensures that all this is readable and understandable by human audiences the bee hive is facing difficulties in the form of illness and weather changes the threat to the hives existence is the plot of this book ensuring flora's survival as she is ultimately deviating from the expected norms this has been compared to 'watership down' which was about the inside world of rabbits i would agree and the former book was one i loved too i so enjoyed this book and would highly recommend it
raw_text.2572: i loved the design covert art for this book that's what originally caught my attention of it in the first place it was just stunning and the story itself just incredible laline paull creates a very realistic if not magical story with the main protagonist being that of a bee who starts off her young life as a sanitation worker bee doing the menial chores for the hive cleaning but with flora 717's unique ability she quickly finds herself making her way steadily through the differing ranks from sanitation worker to forager the ones that go out and find the pollen and bring it back to the hive only to discover that political intrigue is playing a major role behind the scenes as the holy mother's sage priestesses are plotting her downfall to gain the power to rule the hive for themselves i just loved this book the impressive and vivid creativity that went in to this story is unlike anything i have read before and being a debut novel this a goldmine of impressiveness utterly addictive and very compelling thank laline paull for a wonderful book

raw_text.2585: a soon to be classicyes the title of my review may seem to be much hyperbole but i sincerely believe the bees will earn it place beside beloved novels such as watership down and charlotte's web based on the fascinating social behavior of honey bees laline paull has created a vivid compelling world where one's class is immutable and determined at birth a society where imperfection is a crime punishable by death and duty to the hive and love for the queen is life's only reason for being against this backdrop we meet a grand new heroine flora 717 a most unusual bee born into the lowest of the castes sanitation like most of her relatives flora is industrious brave and loyal to her queen however what makes her extremely dangerous is her curiosity boldness and tendency toward self reliance these qualities brand flora a dangerous rebel and in the end she just may be the only hope for her hive ms paull uses the social structure of honey bees as a backdrop to create a saga of surprising drama and power she also masterfully provides commentary on societal issues such as classism political corruption and sexism without ever being heavy handed ms paull's prose is beautifully fluid and descriptive as she guides us through the gorgeous natural world of the bees i loved this book and feel it should be on far more best of lists do yourself a favor and pay the bees an extended visit

raw_text.2600: i was intrigued when i saw this book described as "watership down but with bees " but it isn't really the heroine flora 717 is born into the lowest caste of bees the sanitation workers even though she is usually large for her caste and therefore subject to immediate extermination a member of the priestess caste conveniently appears as whisks her away for an "experiment " after finishing the book oh yes i understand now the political machinations involved flora is allowed access to all parts of the hive and given the opportunity to perform various functions becoming a bit of a mary sue bee in the process when she becomes a forager she is immediately the strongest and most resourceful of the foragers when she meets the queen she becomes the queen's favored companion and storyteller when she is temporarily demoted back to sanitation worker she is acknowledged by her coworkers as the best sanitation worker and so they shield and protect her when she gets up to her illegal shenanigans which include getting pregnant and producing eggs three times i'm not an expert on bee biology but how is that even possible i thought only - well never mind in a sense the bees is like watership down in that flora acts as el ahrairah to her hive ingeniously discovering new sources of food warning the hive of attack identifying the cause of sickness within the hive and rallying her sisters to eradicate it though most of the prose was gratingly florid some of it was really lovely the beech trees surged and shimmered in the wind far below a vixen paused to stare up then melted away stars burned tiny holes in the twilight and then a pale moon traced a slow silver arc through the sky but then the mood is spoiled for me anyway by this flora's heart burst with love for her lost egg and only the shadow of the crow above stopped her sobs to die without holding it again or breathing its sweet and tender scent - and then when it hatched i do have to say though that the conclusion was pretty thrilling and redeemed much of the book for me but still watership down it wasn't

raw_text.2621: the bees is a gallop through a day in the life of a bee as told from a worker bee's perspective the protagonist is flora 717 a bee of very lowly status in the hive from the outset we know that she is no ordinary worker bee and that she is destined for great things the first great thing she does is fight and defeat a predatory wasp the last foragers rushed to get in as a foul alien scent mingled with it sweet and corrupt like rotting fruit it came from the lurid straggle of wasps hovering near the hive drunk and jeering a wave of acrid air rushed in and every sister's feet felt the heavy alien vibration as a great wasp settled on the landing board the wasp was a huge black female with bands of acid yellow and glossy black her head was as large as three sisters' and she used her slashing claws to catch the guards one by one killing each one with a snap of her heavy jaws flora contravenes the hive's highest law of 'only the queen may breed' three times she defies her caste and becomes a forager she tames a drone 'the drones roared and cheered and some grabbed their crotches shouting crude praise for the erotic perfection of this foreign princess' and outwits at least one rodent predator throughout all these episodes there are cute observations of other fauna '717 you are behaving like a demented blue bottle stop that ' in some ways the bees is slightly silly but it's also engaging and instructive i never knew bees did a 'waggle dance' that the hive had such strong stratification of occupations or just how pivotal the queen bee actually is thanks to this anthropomorphic romp i have a new empathy for the lives of honey bees and a deeper understanding of why many people are justifiably worried about their continued existence

raw_text.2625: have you ever read a book that no matter how you try whatever you say falls short words just don't do it justice this is that book it is about a colony of bees from their perspective but is about so much more flora 717 born of the lowest caste is special and the story continues to end defining just how special she is the story delves in the hierarchy of the hive the responsibilities of each bee it talks of their amazing ability to transmit information one to other as to the health of the hive as well as each member and where the foragers can find the best nectar and pollen this is amazing in itself but the story talks of the environmental concerns the dangers to the hive leading us into their lives and makes one remember we are not as unlike other species as we may think if the author writes another book i will read it this quote is quoted in the the book and i even like it "the bee's life is like a magic well the more you draw from it the more it fills with water " ~ karl von frisch
raw_text.2626: this one was certainly strange i don't think i've read a non human driven novel since i was a kid and i don't think i've ever read one intended for adults after a lovely and brief prologue you're with the bees the whole way through flora is our hero a worker bee on sanitation duty out of line right off the bat for looking a little odd and not quite acting the way she is supposed to the bees of this universe don't just buzz around and collect pollen but follow a brutally rigid social structure and obey the hive mind at all costs my first reaction to this universe with actions based on instinct constant reactions to scents and pheromones and vibrations and pulses in the antennae wasn't positive the formalities were a little annoying and the bee world sounded kind of miserable but as flora's character develops and things start to go wonderfully wrong for the hive i was hooked i loved the depth to which paull explores this little hive making it really feel like a universe so that when we finally go outside it's as vast and as dangerous as it would really seem to a bee not only are the interactions all there but so much of the fabricated details the personal relationships between castes the myriad of enemies work so well that they quickly burrowed their way into my brains as facts this is how bees really are the mix of real details only makes that even stronger despite the steepness of the comfort curve this was really a refreshing change i'd read comparisons to the handmaid's tale and it's suitable but with much more action and a little less obvious allegory and bees

raw_text.2631: this review and others are posted at inspiring insomnia bee society is pretty amazing with their tiny brains they manage to form a complex society with a strict hierarchy and rules and functions every bee knows its role in the bees we go one giant leap beyond the real life of these insects to one in which bees talk and socialize with an intelligence comparable to humans the bee characters in the bees are highly anthropomorphized which i expected their society looks and sounds like medieval england which i did not expect since bees have such a highly structured and regimented society and with the presence of a queen bee i can believe that this is what a beehive of talking feeling thinking bees would look like flora 717 is a sanitation worker responsible for the daily cleaning of the hive sanitation workers are the lowest of the low barely worthy of being in the presence of the other bees including foragers nursery workers priestesses and male drones yes i mentioned priestesses the bees is an interesting mix of actual hive life and the author's clever imagination flora quickly distinguishes herself by speaking a skill which no sanitation worker should possess she should have been killed for her failure to toe the line but instead she is allowed to put her talents to use in other areas flora's outlook on life changes when she is allowed to work in the nursery and she must suppress her craving for motherhood since only the queen bee is allowed to reproduce flora also works as a forager and she relishes the freedom of life outside the hive as she breaks free of the hive structure she gains both allies and enemies flora is initially tentative as she tests her boundaries but as she becomes braver and bolder in her challenges the danger to her increases she's a fascinating character and an admirable heroine

raw_text.2640: utterly brilliant full review at word by word here laline paull has channeled an incredible life universe within a beehive seen from the perspective of flora 717 a sanitation bee born with more skills than her kin normally have and accumulates more knowledge that will lead her on a dangerous but necessary path the beehive is like a cult its members knowing their place their role their boundaries however everywhere there are risks and dangers both outside and more dangerously that from within accept obey serve bees read each thoughts receive energy from their queen and their devotions and live in a symbiotic relationship that ensures the safe function and progression of the hive when something threatens that relationship their haven is no longer assured an utterly captivating read and a masterful feat of the imagination paull has the reader on a knife edge knowing the dangers flora 717 faces and yet her discretions feel necessary and we will her to go on and survive and overcome all the challenges she faces could not put it down one of the best reads of 2014 for me

raw_text.2652: despite my long term interest in bees i was a litle shy of this book and wondered how a decent story could be extracted from life in a bee hive the book is award winning not always a good sign for readability however it is a fantastic and enthralling read enlivened by a strong lead character who one finds oneself really rooting for even though it's an insect the character and the indeed the entire hive faces challenges from inside and out throughout the story and this is handled well while the bees are anthropomorphised this is inevitable and the story would not work without it despite a lowly initial status in a tightly hierarchical society by ability and at times sheer heroism bee flora 717 raises herself to an elite status in the hive when true catastrophe strikes she is able to find a way forward and lead the community out of it while the ruling class go into self destuct mode while some of the events seem far fetched laline paull has done her research and most are feasible paull resists the temptation to work in an invasion of varroa mite but the plot is involved enough gripping can't put down stuff hence my unusually high rating for this volume the awards are well earned a literary book that's a good yarn hurrah
raw_text.2653: i heard about this book from my cousin over the christmas holiday break the first book that he recommended was very good which led me to have had high hopes for this book it wasn't bad but it wasn't great the idea behind the story is a very good one the story follows one bee from one cast who lives in a society beehive where the members are known by their number rather than a regular name the downside is that this story would tend to be kind of dull and so this bee breaks away from societal norms and going against the grain this would be alright if somehow it either started a revolution dystopian style or minor infractions were done by multiple people but in this book the main character over and over again doesn't fit the mold and overcomes unbelievable odds to be the best bee at all jobs in the society also there were many times where the book was very predictable for a book that wasn't that long it took me a long time to read it because i wasn't too engaged with it and had trouble forcing myself to pick it up again part of me wishes there was more science in the book to verify which parts are true and which are fiction a lot of the book revolves around the organization of bee society and behavior one example is the waggle dance where bees wiggle to communicate information in the book there are what seems like a lot of embellishments on this so i wonder whether that information is true or if it is fiction there are other things that are mentioned that i don't know about either way and would love to know what is fact and what is fiction furthermore this book had a real opportunity to deal with real world problems like colony collapse disorder but avoided talking about it for the most part i know it was only a work of fiction but there's no reason the science can't be realistic or play a role

raw_text.2667: before i had gotten beyond the first 50 pages i was on the verge of giving this one up i have no particular interest in bees so i found it hard to believe that another 250 pages would be anything but more of the same but i was increasingly impressed with how well researched it was and how skillfully the author translated the nature of bees into behaviour that a reader could understand i found myself marvelling at how the world consists of an immense number of self centred little worlds and throughout i kept drawing parallels to various human orders past and present the numb mantra of accept obey and serve echoes the blind loyalty of the kim clan in north korea ruling by divine right the strict hierarchy of kin could be an allegory of indian caste notion sectarian purges we see all over the place it is like '1984' in bee form and ofcourse the protagonist flora is the hive joan of arc the one who dares question the anonymity of the group but at the same time always putting the love of her kind at the front and revealing the truth about equality at birth i would not be surprised if this shows up as a disney film it has all the ingredients of a heroic cinderella

raw_text.2700: i really enjoyed the bees as the description above suggests the novel is strongly reminiscent of atwood's the handmaid' s tale one of my favourite books however paull put a twist on this by choosing to centre her novel around a bee hive focusing on the trials faced by the insects and the social hierarchy nature assigns for them for me this made the book a very refreshing read and inspired me to learn more about bees i found flora to be a very likeable protagonist who visibly matures and grows in character throughout the novel i do wish there were greater explanations into her special abilities that defy the hive's expectations of her but i do think paull created an excellent and rather inspiring heroine what i also loved about this book was the celebration of motherhood and the relationship between mother and daughter giving some particularly heartwarming moments in the novel my only complaint about the book other than a lack of explanation about flora is that i felt the book was tirelessly trying to put across various messages about the environment about bullies about class and status the book felt disjointed at times jumping from one scene to the next trying to hammer these morals home but didn't succeed really at the heart of this book for me the message is family love and protection of the family that on its own works amazingly well a great debut novel

lack human characters so i was extremely curious to see how this novel would pan out and whether it would live up to expectations the bees starts off strong but it was quickly followed by a lagging middle portion and a semi predictable conclusion though paull clearly did her fair share of research and has a knack for detail i couldn't immerse myself in the world of the hive flora 717 is a worker bee who's always lived by the rules of her hive and her queen she's always known to accept obey and serve her queen in every way possible soon flora discovers that the queen's hive isn't as immaculate as she had imagined and that it's on the brink of crumbling flora soon begins to challenge the tenets she had abided to for so long though the bees features a cast of insects as characters the structure of this novel will feel very familiar for those who read dystopian novels it's a bit difficult to read a novel when you have this nagging feeling that the plot will follow a certain route and my worries weren't for nothing the bees failed to surprise me and i think paull tried to frame it like a dystopian novel so it would fit in perfectly with other novels in the genre paull definitely did a great deal of research for this one and her efforts definitely paid off at times the bees delves into a bit too much detail about bees that i don't think laymen would care for all of the details about the hive queen duties and biological aspects of the bees were nice touches but i feel as if some of the finer details could've been edited out flora is a bee but that never stopped actions and paull failed to develop her character besides a bare bones infrastructure while i expected the bees to be an extremely unique tale it ended up being a pretty average novel that didn't live up to its potential the bees had the opportunity to be one of the best novels of the year but a bland plot and a slow paced plot helped spoil this novel for me the bees was published with a lot of buzz but sadly the novel wasn't as sweet as i had expected it to be

raw_text.2707: i like weird books and totally enjoyed the bees although i'm sure this will not be everyone's cup of tea upon first finishing the bees i felt somewhat dazed i couldn't decide if it was extraordinary and beautiful or if it was intensely strange and perplexing ultimately for me the bees is an intricate combination of both to start you definitely have to be in a specific mindset to read the bees it's not a casual weekend read i could imagine someone picking this up reading the first 40 pages and thinking what the hell and setting it down again the book starts and ends with two short chapters about humans interacting with a beehive in a very matter of fact mundane way very much how most people think about bees hey they're just there to pollinate the orchard and make some honey end of story then the author takes us into the depths of this beehive to follow the inner life of one solitary worker bee flora 717 the beehive is cultish dystopian and violent exerting maximum control over any act of dissent despite the level of control the hive mind exerts over its clan flora 717 manages to evolve and grow experience beauty and life and be a heroine on numerous occasions through little flora 717's experience a reader gets to feel simultaneously insignificant and powerful for me this was quite a memorable read

raw_text.2711: the bees by laline paullin the spirit of george orwell's animal farm laline paull's debut novel the bees wings readers through a life of adventures seen through the lens of flora 717 a worker bee from the titular colony flora is a bee of singular distinction unlike her sisters she is larger stronger and independent with willpower that is unmatched by most other bees in the hive in the world of the hive the queen and the collective are placed above the individual and every bee lives by the credo "accept obey and serve" while for most bees the hive mind reigns flora is an outsider a loner at the centre of this great crowd and beyond her physical intellectual and social differences there is something else she holds secrets we follow her journey through life starting with the moment she emerges from her cell she is a sanitation worker the lowest caste in the hive born only to serve the colony by cleaning the hive but early on we learn that she is unusual whereas other sanitation workers spend their lives shuffling about the hive eyes downcast taking instruction from any and all other bees flora sets herself apart immediately by doing something that no other sanitation worker dares she speaks we witness her education as she performs a variety of roles in the hive a privilege not normally afforded other bees she spends time in the nursery where the queen's eggs develop into the larvae that will soon be new members of their society she works as a forager leaving the hive to hunt for pollen amongst the flowers of the orchard and beyond her travels bring her into contact with other members of the insect world crossing paths with spiders flies and wasps among others they also give her insight into some of the truths and secrets of her society that aren't normally shared with the collective this knowledge and her unwillingness to conform lead to challenges for flora that will test her courage wisdom and perseverance can one bee stand against tradition and the colony beyond the story of flora the bees is a novel that explores a variety of issues and ideas it is a study of a caste based society and the struggles facing anyone who opposes its rigid unyielding structure it explores the inequities of life for those in the lowest strata as compared to those who exist in the circle of influence and power the power in this society is concentrated in the small subset known as sages who act as priestesses of the colony and serve the queen who reigns over all and in the world of this hive this power and control is exerted through blind devotion to the queen and collective the story uses images of religious fervour invoking the traditional language of christianity even going so far as to use a modified version of the lord's prayer at points in the story the religious devotion reaches a cult like fervour with bees following directives unquestioningly and sometimes to their death violence is another theme frequently presented throughout the bees the hive is often portrayed as a police state with the word of the sages enforced by bees serving as police who seem more like assault troops than peacekeepers bees quiver and cower in their presence and punishment by death is prevalent indeed the law of the hive leaves little room for leniency and many bees meet an early death at the hands of these enforcers at other times paull's use of description become nearly erotic the relationship between the bees and the flowers that they search out for pollen is portrayed in tones of yearning and deep need flowers beg bees for their caress wantonly sending out their fragrances in desperate unabashed desire the book also plays with issues of gender politics the fouling of the environment rebirth motherhood loyalty succession and balance it is a study of a society and the struggles of one bee that doesn't fit the mold prescribed for her by that society it is an interesting tale providing insight into the world of bees and a variety of topics for the reader to consider we cheer for flora sympathizing with her as she struggles to do her part to serve her sisters and fulfill her role in the hive while still being true to herself it is a role we can see ourselves in and this little bee exemplifies the courage required to fly in the face of adversity we should all be lucky to be so endowed
raw_text.2712: so i really enjoyed this book i'd never heard of it until a friend of mine picked it up for me and i didn't even realize people would write fiction about bees let me tell you that is my new favorite genre hook me up with bee fiction please the story is interesting if somewhat predictable the parts that were unpredictable ended up being based on inaccurate facts about bee biology beeology but i really didn't mind that at all the author got enough of it right that it was enjoyable and the rest was fantasy enough that i'm willing to suspend my disbelief it's a quick read this book probably took me a total seven or eight hours worth of reading time over two evenings to get through and the language is just really enjoyable to read i will grant that it has the divergent problem of establishing very strict social castes and then doing absolutely nothing at all with them but i feel like they could have been left out entirely and improved the story
raw_text.2713: from the first page of chapter one i found this novel thoroughly riveting the protagonist a bee like all the other characters in this fantasy is flora 717 who is born into a caste of the humblest of workers in a honeybee hive the sanitation workers all other workers are associated with specific flowers where the teasels work the nurseries the thistles guard the hive and sage priestesses govern in the queen's name floras are dismissed as unworthy of differentiation and forbidden to speak but from her emergence in the opening chapter 717 is marked by a sage priestess as unusual much larger and uglier than her kind she speaks and also has the capacity to produce royal jelly called flow at a time when the hive is in dire need of more nurses this first distinction leads to more and flora 717 gradually becomes involved in complicated and dangerous activities she is reminiscent of a cinderella who appears to belong to the scullery but instead finds herself more and more at home in the highest reaches of the hive hierarchy the author laline paull demonstrates all this with a lovely prose style that sounds a bit like that of an ancient royal clan but without detracting from the suspense and action of the plot furthermore the way paull portrays the bees' world through scent heat and movement is effective there were moments of an all too noticeable tendency to anthropomorphize -- a bee prodding another bee with a stick for instance -- but none of the stylistic choices seemed to intrude rather they fade into the background as the bees story that is flora 717's story takes the forefront the bees develop a relationship with flowers by seducing them through pollination they name all the hive's enemies the myriad the first encounter experienced by flora 717 of a battle with wasps is tremendously exciting and they have scent painted histories of the hive in a sort of library the result of all of this is both evocative and beautiful i enjoyed the novel tremendously much as i have previously enjoyed animal fables like narayan's a tiger for malgudi london's call of the wild and adams's watership down paull's belongs in this territory as she focuses on the rhythms and mores of animals even though she eschews using metaphor for political or social allegory this novel begins and ends with the hive effectively dramatizing its life cycle this is underlined by book ending the story with reference to the human owners of the property including the hive and in doing so underlining the indifference of the bees to the humans this is a tantalizing and tremendous fantasy that takes the reader on a wonderful journey into the world of bees

raw_text.2718: flora 717 is a worker bee and the protagonist of laline paull's the bees it may sound completely far fetched to write a story from the perspective of a bee but insanely it worked amazingly well this author clearly did her entomological research the story revolves around a sanitation bee born to a hive where she is at the lowest rung of society in fact others in her kin have not developed speech and she is marked as an oddity at every turn she defies convention and strikes out on her own course fraught with class division religious fanaticism and sexism the bees gave me an entirely new insight into bee behavior and made me crave honey if you're looking for a book unlike any other then i encourage you to give this one a shot unless you're terrified of bees in which case you'd best steer clear

raw_text.2720: how do i even begin to write about laline paull's the bees i simply couldn't review it at first i had half finished sentences such as "made me question so much" and "because bees are weird" and "i have no more words" floating around because i guarantee that it is the weirdest book you will ever read i'm here to help you out - it might be less strange if you know a little bit more about it going in so the bees first and foremost is about bees it is not a metaphor well it could be but stick with me here it is not as my friend presumed a larger analogy for a future dystopian society it is about bees told through the perspective of a bee and stars almost exclusively bees featuring the occasional evil wasp and prophetic spider the novel follows the life of a bee named flora 717 who despite being born a low ranking sanitation bee is almost immediately pushed up the ranks this is because she can is not mute like sanitation workers usually are and is adept at creating flow - the bee version of nursing milk so begins her journey through the rankings of the hive flora is special both by being physically larger and furrier than other bees and through her many unique abilities her place is not at sanitation level but it is fate rather than ambition pulls her through the story i think the most compelling part of this novel is how cultish it is it is absolutely fascinating there were times where i had to remind myself that this was a story about bees and life for them is truly about protecting the hive and the queen first and foremost with possibly a cult like loyalty when translated into human terms but the parallels are uncanny from phrases such as "accept obey serve" referring to the queen bee as holy mother to the use of scent in the hive that calms the bees down making them feel content and though it is never fully explained the hive itself seems to be alive with scent and messages built into its tessellated tiles i think the strangest aspect of the reading experience is not quite knowing where paull stops using factual information and starts using her imagination because the line is thin bees are strange creatures in real life only the queen reproduces male bees do indeed die after mating priestess bees can read your mind if your antennae touch wait that might be one of paull's inventions however i didn't feel that the stakes were high till the final few chapters the ease with which flora initially starts moving between the ranks and the lack of early consequence for her rebellious actions means that i was never very worried for her plus flora is quite an isolated character - partly because she is supposed to be one of many but partly because her interactions with others are either brief or with characters she can't trust with her secrets having stepped away from the book for a while though i would definitely recommend reading this the reading experience is a unique one and you will never look at bees the same way again

raw_text.2722: so my daughter was been wanting to be a beekeeper for years and we are currently researching how one goes about getting started and then i started reading this book for my book club and then halfway through i attended a 3 hour seminar on beekeeping so i suddenly knew all the bee science all in all i was not the same reader when i began the book and when i ended it on chapter one i was a "how can a bee's egg hatch if she has never mated" kind of reader by the the end i was a "how can a bee who has not mated hatch a female worker when everyone knows that unfertlized bee eggs only hatch male drones" kind of reader i don't know which kind of reader it is better to be i don't know as much about spider physiology but i assume that they can all accurately predict the future right the people at my book club who didn't like the book didn't like it because it wasn't the kind of book they wanted to read which is fine enough but i like to judge it based on what it is not what it isn't what it "is" is a story of a single individual fighting against a strict hierarchical collection as that kind of story it mostly works except when she starts to lead the collective against the rebellious individuals then it either adds a deeper layer or else undermines its premise i'm not sure which in terms of the science the author gets all of big things wrong bees are highly democratic not hierarchical other than the queen and all the little things right i was fine with that and fine with following along with flora 717's short lifespan and she tries out all the different kind of bees she could be at the end it might have been a religious allegory but we couldn't come to a consensus on which religion it was allegorizing so we'll leave that one for now four out of five days to feed royal jelly to get a drone

raw_text.2767: accept obey serve this is the motto that must be followed to stay alive in the hive the bees is a uniquely written story that is told from the perspective of flora 717 a bee born into the sanitation unit flora 717's hive is in an orchard and danger comes from many sources both outside and in the queen they must worship ages deformed eggs are being found forager bees are coming back poisoned wasps spiders and crows lurk above the hive and it is being said that winter will come twice flora 717 is unique within the sanitation unit and does not fit in with her sanitation sisters but since variation is not the dreaded deformity she is given jobs elsewhere within the hive as flora 717 proves herself and moves up within the hive she finds trouble flora 717 defies the accept obey serve mantra in order to save her hive an auspicious and of the moment novel for today's society where all bee populations face many of the same threats as flora 717's hive i love that this was written from the perspective of a bee but with all the passion danger and intrigue of a human society that is on the brink of a disaster also while anthropomorphized flora 717 and her hive followed much of the honeybee natural history and behavior while still turning out a riveting fictional story the hive drama and classification of the bees gives a similar feel as a dystopian novel scenes of violence sacrifice and revenge in the bees not only echoes hive life but gives the story an added edge there are also mythical and fable elements that flora 717 encounters my one issue with the book without giving spoilers was how flora came to be in the state she was in it's possible that this was more of a mythical element to the story than a biological one but most of the bee behavior presented was biological anyhow it didn't ruin the story for me at all this book was received for free in return for an honest review
raw_text.2769: reading the bees i quickly realized that this was a story of aliens bees are hive organisms that communicate through dance scent and direct mind to mind contact the reader is immersed in a world with familiar trappings but characters that are the main character is a sanitation bee that conveniently changes roles so that we see almost all the various roles in the hive humans are almost entirely absent making only a handful of appearances instead the story focuses on the other threats to the health of the hive from natural predators to pesticide to internal strife i'm not at all knowledgeable about actual bees so i can't speak to the accuracy of the details but i enjoyed the story and would definitely recommend it and i have a much stronger appreciation for the honey i eat

raw_text.2788: i was pretty into the idea of the bees as soon as i realized that it was in fact a novel about bees written from the perspective of a bee my interest was further roused by margaret atwood's praise atwood being a favorite writer of mine what a fascinating idea to write a book from the perspective of a bee what an incredible challenge laline paull set for herself to make the life and the mindset of a bee comprehensible to human readers without overly anthropomorphizing it's a tricky line for an author to walk and it's impressive that anyone could do it as successfully as paull does here even more impressive that this is her first novel it isn't quite perfect possibly bees are just too freaking alien for it to be a completely smooth process but i was emotionally engaged and i empathized felt the terror of wasp attacks and the horror and dread of the spiders felt the terror and confusion during the visitation and the joy of flight or the queen's love some anthropomorphism is unavoidable in a book like this but i think paull deals with this in a clever way by gradually phasing it out more so in early chapters she writes about the bees voices but the deeper into the text you get the more clear it becomes that a bee's voice is based primarily in chemicals and scents also i kept setting the book down to read about honeybees on wikipedia and so as a result i ended up learning a ton about bees so that's an amazing bonus from what i can tell the depiction of hive life is not strictly accurate i mean obviously right but a lot of the weird stuff that made me go wait what is true to life bees they are totally bananas i'd be interested to hear from people more knowledgeable about bees any apiologists out there read this yet about how well the science holds up besides all that the plot is great the first half did a great job of getting me emotionally engaged with flora 717 and the survival of the hive and then in the second half it was hard to put down a real page turner will flora be ok will the egg survive will the hive survive life or death stakes in the beehive i feel like this is sounding sarcastic but i swear i mean every word i was absolutely caught up in it so ambitious and strange a thrilling read that also taught me shit falls a bit short of perfection but absolutely worth reading if the general premise piques your interest like it did mine 4 5 5 additional note the handmaid's tale meets the hunger games no not at all that's a ridiculous and lazy comparison that doesn't do justice to any of the books in question all of which i like quite a bit
raw_text.2789: i really wanted to love this it has been described as a 'handmaid's tale' for the insect world sounds brilliant right but it just left me cold i just felt that the humanisation of the bees didn't work they're fascinating creatures but trying to impose religion emotions and politics onto their behaviour just didn't work for me i failed to connect with flora 717 the writing lacked enough clarity to offer a good enough explanation of the actual workings of a hive equally the fact that they are bees meant that i drew no interesting parallels with the human condition there were some interesting set pieces outside the hive where flora encounters the outside world and i was kind of charmed by the 'personalities' given to the wasps and other insects but ultimately i found the book a little disappointing shame as the writing although a little overwrought for my tastes was very good unfortunately the comparison with atwood's classic is completely misplaced
raw_text.2790: a handmaid's tale meets hunger games i hadn't thought about that until just now how perfect of a representation that is the bees is a book about flora 717 who came into this world looking different from all others she was bigger her fur was matted and many called her just plain ugly that didn't bother flora she just wanted to learn the book continues with flora's want to learn the problems she causes because she wants to learn and the realization that other bees are trying to take over and create an elite society the book is a little hard to get into it throws a lot of bee biology at you pretty quickly from the beginning and through out the book but if you can take a step back from the technical and just enjoy the story for what it is it's amazing and you won't be disappointed i definitely recommend this book if you really enjoy stories about people who don't care what others think of them hunger games simply because of the rebellion aspect and of course if you're a huge fan of bees
raw_text.2791: the bees is a trip a complex eye opening somewhat terrifying and completely engrossing trip on the inner workings of a bee hive as told through the eyes of one sanitation worker bee flora 717 flora unlike her speechless lowly kin questions her place in her hive but between the queen mother's love fertility police the priestesses sage and accept obey serve discovering any answers is tantamount to treason as flora moves from one level of the hive to the next it becomes clear that there are secrets and flora is keeping a dangerous one of her own when one of those secrets comes out the hive is thrown into chaos it's obvious that paull did her homework the somewhat brutal but efficient way the hive is run can only be a product of nature but the way she added religious zealotry a la orwell's 1984 think big brother but with bees and toed the fine line between imagination and reality to fine tune the inner workings of her hive is purely writer's skill i have never read a book where animal characters were so wholly relatable to me where their fear and struggles and joys could somehow to connect to my own life now i can't help but wonder when i see the bees dipping and diving if they're like flora following the air currents to flowers to forge for pollen or if their anything like the macho drone bees all play and no work but as with the book's epilogue i'm just being a silly human reading too much into things this book while engaging had its slow moments but all of it was build up for the ending where confrontations with spiders battles within the hive and hard truths sprung up one after another there may have been a time or two when the bees became a bit too anthropomorphic but never to the extent that you would feel the bees were in guise of humans flora was a great character and her story was vividly told i will definitely be on the lookout for laline paull's next book if it is as unique and creative as the bees i'm sure to enjoy it
raw_text.2792: this is an odd little book i read it for the usual reasons i like speculative fiction and this seemed reminiscent of margaret atwood's recent trilogy and the outstanding watership down it isn't as good as either of the preceding but was enjoyable as a lighter novel it describes the life cycle of a rebellious bee flora 717 as she rises and falls through the rigid hierarchy of the hive the bee society is marked by pervasive religiosity but the reader will see the ultimate dominance of heredity and gene mutations unfortunately i'm not sure what we were supposed to learn from that duality were they in tension both necessary the themes were a bit muddled but still an interesting read
raw_text.2793: 80 pages shorter and this book would have gotten 5 stars from me a fantastic exercise in imagination anthropomorphized bees that are written with regards to nature nice twists at the end even if it feels rushed
